My advice to those who aren't set on sitting down inside to enjoy their ice cream sundaes, shakes, etc. would be to go around the corner to the "to go" checkout and place your order there, then snatch up any seating you find (I sat outdoors the night I enjoyed my dessert.)
author: Wendy Y.

description:
Definitely a must visit if you're in the area, its a good experience however I didn't really enjoy the "Strike it Rich" sundae that I ordered. Butter pecan ice cream along with vanilla ice cream, almonds, whipped cream and hot fudge in a waffle bowl. 

Easily shareable between 2 people. The ice cream and the waffle bowl weren't that great and unfortunately the best part about the sundae was the hot fudge.
author: Jennifer T.

description:
Best iced mocha I have had in a long while. Made with their very own chocolate and definitely recommended. Top tip: If you are getting drinks or ice cream to go, go uphill around the corner. There IS a sign, but most tourists don't do it. That way you can avoid the masses of lines. 

If you get food to sit down, expect a longer wait. It is a touristy area, so be prepared for masses of people or avoid.
author: Bibi R.

description:
I don't come here every time I visit San Francisco (which is around once a month), but when I do I never regret it.  

We arrived at around 9pm on a Sunday night, surprised that it was still open (until 11pm!).  We were directed downstairs to order, and there were still a lot of people in there!  Regardless, we gave our order (the Gold Rush), got a dollar off with a check in, and meandered upstairs away from the hordes of people to sit down and wait for our ice cream.
 
I expected the server to have a difficult time finding us because we weren't on the main floor, but she found us quickly, within 10 minutes or so, and we were able to eat our diabetes away quite happily.  Regarding the sundae, the Gold Rush was vanilla ice cream with fudge, layers of peanut butter, almonds, whipped cream, and a cherry on top.  Great if you love peanut butter (not great if you don't).  Also, with the dollar off, it came out to just under $10.  Somewhat pricey, but worth a visit once in a while.

Good service, open somewhat late, relatively clean, lots of people, good ice cream (not the best though, go to Mitchell's if you just want rich ice cream!) and delicious chocolate...what more could you ask for?!
author: Vivian L.

description:
CHOCOLATE WASTED! Yep, that's what happened to me and like the regular alcoholic hangover, it did not feel good. I had a mint painted lady and a complimentary Ghirardelli chocolate  square, which was overload. I felt disgusted afterwards, and I even shared the ice cream. Next time, I'll just get a cone or a classic vanilla sundae. 

I do love Ghirardelli Square and think it's a perfect place to take friends or visit if you're a tourist. You get a nice view when you sit on the third floor of the ice cream parlor and it's definitely less crowded than the parlor connected to their chocolate store.
author: Mimi V.

description:
On a nice day in December, the line was through the square.

We came just for some souvenirs to bring home to the family.  Got a free sample of their peppermint-chocolate squares just for walking in!  They have a great selection of the Ghirardelli classics as well as more touristy stuff... And there are plenty of things you can't get anywhere else in the area, so it's worth a special trip rather than a quick stop in a tacky souvenir shop on the Wharf.

Plus, when we went, they were running a special on their bars-- and when the CalTrain failed on the way home, we had a milk chocolate toffee bar for sustenance. I suppose I owe my survival to Ghirardelli... I certainly owe them a positive review!
author: Allison M.

description:
Visiting Ghiradelli is like a chocoholic's dream (which I am not but my husband is).  Sure it's touristy, overpriced, and not the best chocolate. Still, it holds a special place in our hearts and whenever we visit it's like a nostalgic trip down memory lane.  

While I perused the mounds of wrapped, bagged, boxed, chunk, and bar chocolate, my husband schmoozed with the greeter handing out chocolate at the entrance to the chocolate shop.  He had a great time reminising about all of the great Ghiradelli creations of the past, like tube chocolate (discontinued because of the Tylenol scare) and how Ghiradelli Square has changed over the years.  Apparently the greeter has been working for Ghiradelli since the early 80s and she is a fixture in the place. The entire time they were talking, she kept handing him samples of chocolate (which he LOVED).  I think he must've eaten at least 10 pieces of chocolate!  

Thanks Ghiradelli for making our visit to SF sweet!
author: Kelly K.

description:
My friend Eleanor came visiting from Oregon, and even on a cold rainy night she really wanted ice cream.  We dropped into the ice cream soda fountain at Ghirardelli Square to take care of her ice cream fixation.  I'm lactose intolerant so I really take it easy on dairy products, even frozen ones, as often as I can.  I've said it before, and I'll say it again ... Thank goodness for the makers of Lactaid tablets.

Eleanor had the Butterscotch Hot Fudge Sundae, but since I was paying I wasn't about to just sit there and watch her eat.  I ordered the Golden Gate Banana Split for myself.  It had been ages since I've had a banana split so I was really looking forward to this.

You enter the fountain at Ghirardelli, you study the menu, you place your order and pay for it then you take your numbered sign with you to grab a table somewhere.  The soda fountain was pretty empty on the night that we went, and before we could settle into our seats our dessert treats arrived.  They gave us extra spoons I guess so we could try each other's dessert.  That wasn't going to happen though.  I hate butter pecan ice cream, and my friend said she hated bananas.  

My Golden Gate (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/vzBSlQezq2GJkDeqBQxdtw?select=wF8NALOOlPtbUsOrsGPVjA) looked delicious.  I can't describe it any better than the menu which describes this treat as, "A trio of vanilla, strawberry and chocolate ice cream each paired with perfect toppings - crushed pineapple, sliced strawberries and homemade chocolate syrup.  All finished with fresh bananas, whipped cream, chopped almonds and a cherry."  Was it everything described?  You betcha!  Was it good?  It was incredible!

Prices are a bit on the high side, but I was there to enjoy good company so I really didn't care.  Friendly staff.  Fast service.  Real ice cream with real chocolate.  Lactose intolerance?  Bite me!
author: Wilhelm Y.

description: Wow, this place is certainly expensive. $10 sundaes. The little squares of chocolate are 85 cents. Bonus right now is bag of 80 for $27. Dang that seems too much to me. It's been 12 years since I was last here and I do not recall sticker shock on prior visits.
author: Dr. Snarkenstein Y.

description: Place was packed, but everyone was pleasant & courteous. We didn't stand long in line to purchase our chocolate
author: Magda F.

description: Very good ice cream. Excellent quality. I love the ambiance of this place so much, I even choose to work outside of this establishment as a professional clown on many days.
author: Kenny T.

description:
This place is 5 stars if you are a young couple in love, visiting San Francisco for the first time and want to go back home with fond memories of your trip to the City by the Bay. You will be staring into one another's eyes not aware of the surrounding chaos associated with eating at this establishment.

For everyone else, in my opinion, 1 star is more appropriate.  I LOVE Ghiradelli Chocolates and Ice Cream. I've been to their San Diego, Monterey, San Leandro and San Francisco locations multiple times and have and will continue to buy their chocolates but I regrettably say that after bringing locals and out-of-towners to this location for the past 15 years each ensuing visit feels more chaotic than the previous. I also say this after our group just finished eating at perhaps equally crowded Boudins. Our experience at Boudins was much better in terms of service, food quality, seating, etc.

Pros:
- Great Chocolates including the free sample that you get upon entering store side
- Great Ice Cream (when frozen)
- Cool working Chocolate Rolling Machine in Back of Store

Cons
- Bad place for any party larger then 2 or 4. We had 9 adults and 5 children. 
(Trying to find seats on an actual subway platform during rush hour would be a good way of describing the chaos and conditions that we encountered. After looking for 5 minutes for ANY table adjoining or not, we thought it appropriate to ask for assistance from the staff. This was met with a what-are-you-kidding-me-look along with a flustered response that we were on our own to arrange for seating. I've had more assistance getting group seating when I've gone with friends and family to a HomeTown Buffet.)

- 20 Minute wait for Food to be served (Quality of course takes time right? Please keep reading)

- Ice Cream Soup was served to us
(No, not just the sundaes we ordered but even the Ice Creams Scoops in a Bowl. Why make us wait 20 minutes to get our Ice Cream if they will be melted upon arrival? If the premium in price we are paying is NOT for service as shown above, then it must be for the quality of the food. Alas, that was not the case.)

- No Bathrooms in or near store
(The lovely folks that manage the whole Ghirardelli square thought it appropriate to share bathrooms with the 1-2 dozen other shops in the square. The ladies standing 10 deep in line outside while it was raining to use these bathrooms did not seem too pleased with this particular use of efficiency.)

- Broken Exit Door with No Sign
(We pushed then pounded on an exit door 3-4 times before turning around wondering what was happening. The cashier annoyingly looked at us and told us that this particular door was broken. As some would say: Whats it take to put up a sign, a cone, caution tape, a handwritten napkin?)

All the staff was busy, busy, busy, like bees buzzing within a hive. I just wish I could've said our groups' experience was like honey...it wasn't.
author: Atif Q.

description:
Because of Yelp reviews, I knew to head over here through the retail side so that I could get a free sample. When I walked in, yep - I got a milk chocolate truffle sample and was nearly overwhelmed by all the chocolate all around. I didn't actually buy anything though.

It was neat to see the displays in the amazing various colors they had. I actually didn't know that Ghirardelli was based in San Francisco until I came into town. Guess I had never looked hard enough at the logo! Anyhow, they have a brief machine set-up in the soda fountain area that showed how chocolate is made Ghirardelli's way. It was pretty neat to check out.

Duke D. and I wanted to make sure we got something good here so we ended up choosing the Gold Rush Sundae. I knew he loved peanut butter, so it was the choice. Vanilla ice cream with melted peanut butter, hot fudge, caramel, whipped cream, and a Maraschino cherry on top - how do you not feel guilty about that? However, the melted peanut butter was just a brilliant idea because it really mellowed out the entire dessert. Usually peanut butter and chocolate desserts have one overpowering the other but this was just perfect. I'm pretty sure I lost his heart over this dessert - I even caught him at some point during the rest of our day daydreaming about the dessert and not me. Too good - worth the ~$9.
author: Minerva T.

description:
A fan of their ice creams!! I tried their Black Forest Cherry Sunday and it's great!! 

The day we went the line was shorter and the service was fast. We were able find a place to sit relatively easy... just wish the place is a bit cleaner!!
author: Ravi C.

description:
Eh... To be honest, I believe this place is hyped up a tad TOO much. 
 
-There's a plethora of tables for customers to sit: outside seating, downstairs seating, and upstairs seating. 

-You get to watch how chocolate is made through the machines.  You see what they go through to create the gooey, fudge. 

-They bring you your order. (I'm always a big fan of dessert places that bring me my food instead of just handing it to me over the counter). 

The thing is I felt like I was just at any ordinary ice cream shop with Ghiradelli chocolate cloaked on top.
author: Feefz M.

description: Great place and atmosphere if your taking rinds from out of town. It's one of those places they're going to want to visit
author: Yasin S.

description:
Came here Sunday night at 10:30pm... +1 Star for being open late.  The cashier who took my order (early 20s blond hair, African American girl) was so RUDE! She yelled at me to hurry up my order just because I turned around to ask if my husband wanted anything else.  Well we would have ordered more but that bi$## made me lose my appetite.  

Our sundae came out completely melted and dripping off the sides.  The "drinking chocolate" came out only 1/2 full.  

Would I come back? No.  Would I recommend it?  No.
author: Yvette T.

description:
It is a pretty touristy spot, but you will forget all about that when you enter chocolate heaven. 

Go for one of the many sundaes that they have and be prepared for the food coma that results.
author: Raza H.

description: It was cool seeing the original factory and shop but otherwise its an overrated tourist spot which I wouldn't of ever gone too unless someone made me go. The chocolate was alright, and the hot cocoa I got was also very average for the price I paid I felt a bit ripped off... I will stick back to my Belgium and Swiss chocolates thank you very much.
author: Vanessa S.

description:
We came here the saturday after Black Friday so of course the line was out the door, up the walkway and around the fountain.  Be we were sucking up it up and going to wait in line ... in the freezing SF cold. 

The line moved really fast and before I knew it I had ordered and was waiting for my order at the counter.  The rest of my group got table numbers so their order could be delivered to them.  I ordered to go since we were sitting outside so I had to wait inside for my order.  10 minutes later I had my order and walked out to meet the family.  Their order took about 10 more minutes to arrive so I had to giggle. But the sweets were yummy and the customer service was FANTASTIC!  The place was a mad house and these servers were working their tails off yet they all had the best attitude which is why I really gave this 4 stars.
author: Christie B.

description:
The first time I spotted Ghirardelli was while I was out exploring Fisherman's Wharf and beyond. In the beyond, meaning out on the sea/harbour wall, I looked back towards the shore only to see a gigantic sign saying Ghirardelli. Everyone knows this means chocolate. I went.

My second visit to Ghirardelli was to introduce a friend to it. So, on the same walk to Fisherman's Wharf minus the trot out onto the sea/harbour wall, we headed for an afternoon treat. The Presidio Passion to be exact. Layers of ice cream, strawberry and chocolate fudge. Two spoons. Topped with a chocolate covered strawberry. The desserts are pretty massive! So if you'll be riding that trolley on back up the hills, one dessert is more than enough for two people to share.

You order at the front. Then if you're hangin' out, you'll get a table number. Sit on down wherever you like. Your goodies will show up from there.

I'm not sure if it's seasonal or just on demand... but when the upstairs is open, it serves as a hot chocolate counter and chocolate shop.
author: Wendy P.

description: White chocolate mocha, hot or iced is to die for and worth the price!  Buyer beware, once you walk in to the amazing smell and see the delicious options you will enjoy a worth calorie fest!
author: Jennifer R.

description:
Very touristy place but somehow I came here since I couldnt think where else to go at that moment for dessert. I got the salted caramel hot chocolate and it was delicious. It wasnt too rich or too sweet so it was great! Not too hot that it burns your tongue too. Haha

But when I was almost done, it got a bit saltier so I didn't finish it anymore. 

My boyfriend got the sundae and it was probably the best sundae I ever had. I am not usually a fan of sundaes because its just way too sweet!! But there's is not overly sweet at all! You can really taste the quality of the chocolate. I was impressed. I wouldn't mind coming back. We were lucky it was raining and not that busy with tourists so we found a place to sit and relax. I love the free chocolate samples too!
author: Sarina A.

description:
How can you mess up an ice cream sundae? Use the blandest ice milk you can find, add overly thick and sweet goo on top and slather it with non dairy whipped topping. 
I gave two stars because the staff is nice.
author: A G.

description: I guess as a visitor to SF one would have to visit the famous ghiradrdelli ice cream shop right? They give out free samples of the classic chocolate squares. I'm kind of shocked they they do considering how much they cost.. but hey! Free for us! They now have two stores that sell their classic ice cream and desserts, one on top of another. So now you can get your orders quicker! Personally I had to try their classic ice cream Sunday. It was really good! Probably the best one I have ever had. However, I don't think it was worth the $10... :( sorry. But it was nonetheless really good!
author: Connie V.

description: Got the crissy fields sundae and it was super yummy! It's basically two scoops of cookies n creme on each side and vanilla in the middle, with cookie chunks and two pieces of chocolate all over. Had a ton of whip cream to top it off. The portion was so huge and we tried, but still couldn't finish. Super fast service and a wonderful atmosphere. The cookie chunks were such a plus and went right with the ice cream which melted in your mouth. Definitely looking forward to come back again!
author: Sharon Y.

description:
At first, this place is overwhelming.  After you walk around a little bit you realize you're in heaven.  For chocolate lovers like me, it's such a great experience to be in there.  Even for non chocolate lovers, you have to go here to say you've been at the original ghiradelli! 

I didn't like the huge lines, I felt like that could be a little better handled.  But at the end of the day, this place is amazing!  The scenery is beautiful around it.  The employees are really nice.
author: Nora F.

description:
Complete tourist trap.  If that's what you are looking for, then it's not necessarily a bad thing, just know that you are going to WAY overpay for an ice cream or dessert that you could get for less than half the price at any Baskin Robbins or Dairy Queen at home.  

We got what amounted to a $10 sundae that was fine but completely unremarkable.  Serves me right really, but my wife wanted to say we'd been there and we really didn't have time that day to check out the true artisanal dessert shops that SF might have to offer.

A quick check of Yelp tells me that there are a ton of cool places we could have gone.  Bummer.
author: Darrin M.

description:
This place NEVER fails me!! I always had to make a pit stop here whenever I'm in SF! The same with their other location in SD. But of course, going to the original O.G. is a must! Once you go in, be expected to get a sample of their chocolate square! It changes daily, but whenever I go it's usually the caramel. Also expect to smell nothing but YUMMY chocolate heaven! Sadly, chocolate and ice cream is definitely my weakness, but what can I say? Can a girl indulge a little?? haha..

My favorites from Ghirardelli are the Gold Rush (basically with chocolate and peanut butter - any peanut butter lover's DREAM!) and the Mint Bliss (dark chocolate syrup with dark chocolate and mint chocolate ice cream - i would get this if i wasn't with my fiance LOL)  

The only con about this is that, you're paying about $8-9 for a sundae, but it's not any ordinary sundae though when you think about it! ;) Another thing to keep in mind is to expect longggggg lines since it is a tourist area.
author: Sam W.

description:
If you're not going there to get an ice cream sundae, dont go!

Apart from touristy stuff, the chocolate selection is basically just bags of their chocolate squares. If you go there looking for interesting chocolate selections you'll probably be disappointed.

But the ice cream sundaes there are amazingly decadent! If you just see them you'll probably be seduced. Try going towards the evening time when the tourist crowd is less and you can walk towards the park and enjoy the ice cream with a great view rather than loud families from idaho shouting in your ear about what time the need to leave for the airport or the banjo player asking for money across the road.
author: Ash S.

description: We parked nearby and parking was free. It was free for 4 hours. We walked into the store first and each got a free sample of chocolate. Then we went to order sundaes. There was no wait. We went on a weekday around noon. My daughter ordered the mint chocolate sundae. She ended up switching it to be all mint icecream. She didn't care for the dark chocolate hot fudge. I ordered the brownie sundae and switched the vanilla ice cream to mint chocolate chip. I asked for the brownies on the side but they but 2 pieces on it and one on the side. Not sure why they did that? My husband and son shared a cookie crumble sundae. We all enjoyed our sundaes. We also looked at the mini tour that showed how they make chocolate.
author: May P.

description:
This is a cool landmark to visit, and the square is nice at night, but I didn't find anything special about the ice cream here. Seemed like your typical sundae. The silverware has definitely seen better days, to the point where I almost didn't want to use it and only ended up having a few spoonfuls of ice cream.

The system here definitely needs work, as it's currently ass-backwards. First you order, then you scramble to find a table while holding onto an order number card attached to a holder that belongs on a table. While this is going on, there are servers scrambling to fulfill orders. This generates chaos, and this establishment would be better suited as a sit-down style restaurant with the other location (a few steps away) remaining "fast food/takeout" style.

The staff was also pretty rude, treating people like cattle by trying to herd them to their other location. In the end, we came to enjoy a nice sundae at a landmark, but ended up in a badly managed tourist trap.
author: Nikos M.

description:
I know- I know- this is a sweet tooth's fantasy.  

I know I shouldn't have even bothered Yelping this place.

I know how much I will hate myself for even coming here.

I know I will suffer at the gym the following day.

Oi vay.

I caved.  I looked at their shakes and sundaes (I wanted the sundae) but I got a one scoop chocolate, no, make that a Ghirardelli chocolate scoop of ice cream w/ a chocolate rim waffle cone.. 

As I sat outside to enjoy the scenery and to enjoy my ice cream, I almost did not regret buying it.  I also almost did not regret finishing it.  OMG, it was so rich and good but not overly sweet.  I am glad I tried because after the MANY, MANY years of visiting and living in SF, I never tried this place!


However, my want was still not satisfied as I still want the sundae still.
author: Tram N.

description:
My boyfriend and I went out on a limb and decided to come here to demolish the EARTHQUAKE...we did :)

Many people all around us stared at us like we were crazy but it was one of those things on our list to do together. We accomplished it...1hr later haha but it was so worth it. The whipped cream made us sick to our stomachs but we pushed it aside and ate all the ice cream, bananas, and strawberries. 

It was BOMB.
author: Serena F.

description: I think the location is beautiful and artsy. It is definitely a place you can come to drink hot cocoa and read a good book. The hot cocoa wasn't that great though, which I found to be in all ways wrong considering that they are a chocolate company. You gotta get chocolate right if that is your trade! lol
author: Leeanna C.

description: Ordered a couple of sundaes to share. Sundaes were good, but not the best I've had. Service good. Will probably return on a nice warm summer day.
author: Angela D.

description:
I came here with a couple of my friends yesterday on Halloween night and surprisingly, I've never been to this part of San Francisco - at least I don't remember being in the area.  I didn't know this place existed until my friend told me where we were going in San Francisco.  

When we arrived, there was no line and we looked at the menu on what to order.  Everything looked good and sounded good on the menu.  I ordered a Large Butterscotch Fudge Sundae ($8.71 with tax) and my friends ordered a Large Hot Fudge Sundae and a Hot Fudge Peanut Butter Sundae (both the same price as mine).

We sat down and waited for our order to come.  It wasn't too long of a wait.  I didn't try my friends' sundaes but I'm sure they tasted good.  My Large Butterscotch Fudge Sundae was pretty good.  As I was reaching the bottom of the cup, there was A LOT of butterscotch sitting at the bottom.  That mixed with the melted vanilla ice cream and it was pretty sweet.  The fudge was good and pretty much up to par of what I thought of Ghirardelli chocolate.  The best fudge I ever had!

The store had a wide selection of Ghirardelli chocolate and I saw an umbrella they sold there which I thought was made of chocolate because of the handle.  To my amusement, the handle wasn't chocolate and my friends had a good laugh from that.

As we left around 11:25pm, there was a long line out the door.
author: Daniel H.

description:
we ordered the coffee ice cream and shared it- delicious!
They also give you a free piece of chocolate at the register
author: Kerri T.

description:
The two stars they do get is for the creamy ice cream and for the blonde kid that delivers the items to the tables.  We were greeted by a nice older lady when we walked in and she was giving out samples. We then made our way to the order counter where a guy rang us up and gave us a number to put on our table.

While we were waiting, what seemed like forever for our ice creams, one of the bussed kids dropped some hot chocolate behind our table in the doorway.  I knew it was hot because I felt it on my foot and then the smell of chocolate. The contents of the drinks ended up landed on my feet and the back of my jeans and then on another lady's bright pink sweatshirt.  The kid was quick to apologize and asked if everyone was okay, I felt bad for him because you could tell that he felt really bad and was having an off day. While he was cleaning his mess Anthony came to the area and asked if we were okay and as soon as my sister told him that a lot of it got on the other lady, we no longer existed.  The only reason Jason (mgr) found out was because she threw a fit of how she couldn't go around looking like that and was wanting another shirt. Anthony either never told Jason about me too or Jason didn't care to check on me himself. 

Our items came while I was in the restroom cleaning my foot off and the blonde kid remade it for me when I asked.  

I don't feel like they cared that a hot drink was spilled and ruined my jeans and burned my foot and Anthony shouldn't work with the public because he doesn't seem to care about anything dealing with people.
author: M G.

description:
Yeah okay so what. This of cause is a huge tourist location. It's way crowded. Way over priced and way just.....  There are so
Many local great ice shops in SF. This is not one. Make sure you share to off set the huge $10 price for a mediocre scoop
author: Howard C.

description:
I always come here whenever I go to the city. The workers are very friendly and they are always accommodating. I am honestly in love with Ghirardelli sundaes and the fact that the people who work there give me good service, it makes it that much more enjoyable. 

This is a really nice sit-down spot to enjoy amazing ice cream and hot drinks when visiting the city.
author: Parwana W.

description: I was there Sunday night and I truly wish I could remember my cashiers name. She was absolutely the sweetest girl and so helpful and patient with my family who doesn't speak English. It was their first trip to SF from Mexico and I thought it would be a good idea to take them for dessert there. I want to say her name started with a J... Jennaly?! Gosh I know it was with a J but i can't remember. She was a sweet African American girl who was at the register closest to the exit. I currently have pregnant brain so I can't remember what I even ate two hours ago. But my family gushed about how wonderful she was. The tiniest gestures make such an impact, that even her patience and offering to warm up their chocolate chip cookies made their evening that much sweeter. I'll be back soon! Thank  you!
author: Anali G.

description: Excellent!  The best ice cream and chocolate shoppe ever! I've never been to SFO without eating here!
author: Todd C.

description:
When I first moved out to SF over a decade ago, I did all the touristy stuff, including Ghirardelli Square and the Ice Cream shop. It was expensive, sure ($6) but was a MASSIVE sundae and so delicious!

So where else would I take guests who visit and have never been??

Anywhere but here!

1) The lines are a mile long. They go out the door and around the corner -- so you can go upstairs to the "express" line which only go half a mile long, and out the door...  Expect to wait 30-60 minutes to get some scoops of ice cream...

2) The prices are insane. $10+ for a sundae!  (and you thought Frappaccinos were expensive!)  The size is no longer as massive as I remember it.  A brownie sundae is 2 average-sized scoops of ice cream in what appears to be a 16 ounce cup, and they don't even give you a FULL brownie with it (same for the cookie sundae) -- they give you HALF of one.  For $10?!?  Weak, weak, weak, weak, weak.

The ice cream is fairly good and the fudge sauce is delicious, but serve that up with a side of boredom and impatience from standing in line, smothered in empty-wallet-syndrome, and with a dollop of bad attitude from the servers (they seem to hate working there, but quite frankly I can't say I blame them), and that is one bitter sundae you end up having to swallow
author: Matthew G.

description:
I'm a sucker for sweets, and this place has an abundance of them. Prices are high but the ice cream, candies, brownies, cookies, etc. are just so, so good.

Make sure you use the Yelp check-in special when coming here! $1 off sundae's I think it was. I forgot to do it before I paid =(
author: Kevin S.

description:
Expensive, but quite good. Where else do you go for chocolate and ice cream at Ghiradelli Square?

Make sure to pick up a coupon before you go...they are everywhere in SF.

Glad we could justify our splurge by all the walking we did.
author: Drake L.

description:
G ood stop for out-of-towners to pick up gifts for back home
H ot Fudge Sundae is worth it for locals to brave the tourists
I t's quite possibly the best in San Francisco
R est assure, it's worth the $10 price tag
A h, that signature fudge drenching two scoops of creamy ice cream 
R eally nothing else like it -- it sets the sundae apart
D on't forget to add the chocolate-dipped Waffle Bowl for $1 more
E at and disregard everything -- the price, the calories, the crowd
L ine to order starts at the entrance to the left of the shop
L ook for seats upstairs after you pay to avoid the foot traffic
I n no time, the runner will find you and deliver your delicious treat
author: Anthony N.

description: Worth the wait to share the experience of this ice cream shop with my son for his birthday. The teenagers working there seemed to really enjoy their job, which made it fun for my 9 year old.  Ice cream was delicious!!
author: Jayne E.

description:
1 star for the bf taking me here after our X-mas dinner a couple nights before the actual day...soo cute!   He knew that I have never actually walked through Ghirardelli Square & planned for us to go to the shop after dinner & walk through the square.  Too bad it was raining that night!  

It was hard to decide what to get, but we ended up ordered a sundae with bananas and plenty of gooey fudge and chopped almonds.  They're big...but despite being a tourist trap, it was  pricey.. our sundae was almost $9; & from what I remember, these babies aren't nearly as big as the ones at Fenton's .  Since it's soo packed & big in there, by the time the servers find you, your sundae is starting to melt.

It's a nice place for a local or a Bay Area native to go for a change of scenery or "special occasion" but, I'm rarely in an ice cream sundae mood and all they have is ice cream based or hot cocoa!  I'd prefer to go elsewhere for desserts whenever I have a craving for them in the city but I wouldn't mind going back when I'm in the mood for splurging (key word, splurging) for ice cream.
author: Cat C.

description:
There's a reason this place has almost 800 Yelp reviews and averages four stars. A must for anyone visiting San Francisco, it's even better if you love chocolate. On the retail side of the house, free samples are offered as you walk in the door. Nice touch. I got a milk chocolate caramel square, and it almost tempted me to buy a bag. Almost.

The ice cream sundae / milkshake side of the house is efficient and offers up many tasty chocolate treats. Full from a big dinner, I opted for a small hot chocolate which warmed me up nicely. (It was only 55 degrees in the middle of July, with a brisk wind blowing in from the water.) My companions ordered a range of goodies, from the signature ice cream sundae to the mint chocolate chip milkshake, along with chocolate covered strawberries. All-in-all, everyone left happy and satisfied.

The interior could be a little cleaner, but overall this "Manufactory" of chocolate - their word, not mine - tames the chocolate beast within. Enjoy!
author: Maria S.

description: This place is more of a novelty than anything else. Of course the ice cream is delicious, but the line was so long, and the restaurant was so crowded, that it kind-of took away from the whole experience. My friend who lives in the area told me Ghirardelli is always like that.
author: Larisa H.

description:
Yay Ghiradelli chocolate! Known for it's yummy and mouth melting chocolate, and a name i seem to misspell all the time. 

But enough about their name and chocolate.. They make ice cream? WHOAAA!! I have never had or heard of ghiradelli making ice cream. So i decided to get myself a cone! Along with a cookie and a cappacinno.

I....
- ordered a cookies and cream ice cream on a chocolate dipped cone. 7$?
-a regular cookie, which was huge btw 5$
-coffee (for my husband) 5$

So let me start off and say that the bill was crazy expensive. I know we are in SF but wow i had to double take on the price.

The ice cream was really good. Why? It had large pieces of oreo cookies in it. The cookie however was a shortbread style. It was very hard and dense. And the flavor was very lacking. I did not get to taste the coffee. My husband drank it like water. :( He said the flavor was good, But it seemed like it had less than half filled. Most of the cup was filled with foam.

I do like where this place is located. Right across the street there is a park and a peir.  Parking however can be difficult to find. But luckily they are located near a parking facility that validates! YAY!
author: Eleanor D.

description:
The staff here seriously has some major attitude...My uncle ordered an iced tea and it came out to be a glass of warm water with a tea bag in it plus two ice cubes...Asked if there was some other kind of iced tea and the guy answered me: "This is not a Quickly!" Extremely impolite and rude...I will give some credit for the display and the taste of the Banana Boat though. it was great for sharing!

However, I will not be back to this place because of the service.
author: Anny H.

description: Chocolatey heaven on earth. The sundaes *looked* to die for, like a classic old fashioned painting. sad face- solo Jenn did not partake. I did get a decent, but not nearly as decadent, to-go strawberry chocolate shake though which I hopefully burned off at least partially while climbing back up the crazy steep street. The best chocolate I took home was their new mint chocolate chip cookie bar. A-mazing!
author: Jenn K.

description: My favourite for years.. Come here once a month.. Live their espresso chip with milk hot fudge... Their hot fudge is what makes the ice cream taste soooo good.
author: Purvesh K.

description:
The World According to Noelle
Allergic Girl's Guide to Life

This particular location is cozy meaning small and packed to the gills with chocolates. Came here after tea at Crown & Crumpet. Purchased six of their amazing chocolate chip cookies and bittersweet chocolate sauce for ice cream. Staff is extremely friendly and helpful. 

5 stars for excellent customer service
5 stars for great chocolate products
2.5 stars for location
2.0 for size of shop

The Ghirardelli Chocolate Shop in Monterey, California is much more spacious. My favorites are their chocolate chip cookies, salted caramel hot chocolate and their coffee ice cream :)

Noelle's Notes
Don't forget to get your parking validated!
author: Noelle J.

description: Delicious sundaes and banana splits. Prices are moderate to expensive and portions are smaller than the price demands.
author: Nathan R.

description: Was here back in 2008 during the game developers conference. Had breakfast here before flying back to L.A. There's nothing like a sumptuous, gooey hot fudge sundae for breakfast to really give your inner child something to cheer about. Servings were heaping and spectacular. Early in the morning, these guys were the only ones open so we got in and out with no traffic.
author: Ebony M.

description:
Every time I'm in San Francisco, I make a point of stopping by for an ice cream sundae and some chocolates to bring back home. As mentioned ad nauseum by other Yelpers, the place is full of tourists like me (but I'm a considerate tourist :) ) during the summer, so don't come here expecting a quiet, relaxed atmosphere. And don't be surprised if there is a long line at the ice cream shoppe, though the line moves relatively quickly. Once you place your order, you are given a number placard that you place on your table which is used by the servers when they bring you your ice cream. Service is friendly and fairly efficient, though if you come at a busy time, your ice cream might be half-melted by the time the server tracks you down, especially since you probably ordered a hot fudge sundae (which is what I'd recommend you order, but more on that next).

I went to SF twice last summer, and both times, I dropped by for a sundae. The first time, I ordered the Mint Bliss Sundae (Chocolate and Mint Chocolate Chip Ice Creams, Hot Fudge, Whipped Cream, and a Mint Bliss Square), and the second time, I got the Gold Rush Sundae (Vanilla Ice Cream, Hot Fudge, Peanut Butter Sauce, Whipped Cream, Cherry, and a Peanut Butter-Filled Milk Chocolate Square). Both were delicious, and in both sundaes, Ghirardelli's hot fudge was the star. It is exceptionally smooth, dark, and rich, and it is the highlight of the sundae. The hot fudge really makes you want to lick your bowl clean. Alas, I care enough about my public image to exercise the tremendous amount of restraint necessary to not lick every last drop of hot fudge out of the bowl. I'm a sucker for anything that has peanut butter in it, so the Gold Rush Sundae was particularly satisfying.

Be warned, though,  that the sundaes are very sweet, perhaps borderline excessively sweet, so if you are not a fan of having your teeth nearly get to the point of hurting from the sweetness, these sundaes may not be for you. You should probably take advantage of the water that is available for free inside of the cafe.

While, for the most part, I am a fan of the ice cream sundaes here, my biggest gripe is the price. Plain and simple, I think that these sundaes are a bit overpriced. $8.95 for two scoops of ice cream, some hot fudge, and toppings? Really??? I mean, I get that this is a tourist attraction, but there is no way the sundae should cost so much when you can get sundaes from a Dairy Queen or Friendly's for $4-6.

In summary, I'd definitely recommend stopping by Ghirardelli Square for chocolates, and if you have no fear of sweetness, check out the ice cream shoppe while you're at it. While the price:value ratio isn't great, the sundaes taste good enough that you (momentarily) forget that you just got hosed.
author: Kevin C.

description: Oh.My.GOD! I LOVE this place. No words can describe how delicious it is.
author: Katina M.

description:
Why if this isn't the most overrated tourist trap...

I'm not one for touristy spots and I really dislike anything sweet-tasting, but my SF-local friend insisted I give this place a try on my visit last Christmas. I gave them the opportunity to change my preconception but they even went as far as going lower than what I expected.

There was hair in the ice cream. LONG, THICK, BLACK hair in white, vanilla ice cream. How in the world could they have missed that? I went with a large group so I got to try a variety of their offerings. All of them were overly sweet and sugary; even the dark chocolate dessert was overwhelmingly sweet.

Service was also extremely slow and inefficient. I wasted over half an hour waiting for the deserts to come. Really, I wasted an entire night coming here. Never again.
author: Alexandra M.

description:
My rating is biased as I frequent Disney California Adventure land often and get the Ghirardelli store experience there without the 30 minute wait. 

Having visited this place during a trip to SF I encountered a massive line, which unfortunately I had to wait in, since my boyfriend believed that "when in Rome" he needed to order a sundae. 15 minutes waiting in line to order than another 15 minutes waiting for his very plain sundae to go, we gave up and asked for a refund. 

IF you're wondering what to order though, get the shake with the banana and chocolate in it. It is absolutely delicious. I've had that from the Disney location and loved it. Most of the sundaes look very plain, keep in mind that they use basic Dreyer's ice cream so really you're paying for their fudge.
author: Roxanne G.

description: Good morning! This was the biggest ice parlor and candy shop I've seen together. Its sooo cute! You walk in threw the gift shop and once you wrap around to the register. There's the ice cream parlor! It was the biggest assortment of Ghirardelli ice cream I've ever seen! Plus the ladies working there were incredibly patient with my indecisiveson who was overwhelled by all the chocolate when ordering! We're defiantly going back!!
author: Kay O.

description:
Dark, Milk, Raspberry, Peanut Butter, Sea Salt, Caramel, etc. When you're in SF stop by and get your chocolate fix here! As you walk in you are greeted by wafts of sweet decadent chocolate air and tempting caramel drizzle. 
I had their Sea Salt Caramel Sundae, which I know was made for 2 people but I finished and I didn't care who was judging me! The fudge was thick and sweet, perfect combination of sweet vanilla ice cream, decadent caramel and to bring everything together, sea salt, which brought even more of the flavor out. I didn't purchase any of the chocolates but if I were a chocolate lover this would be the place to spend my hard earned money. The place is huge and they have a sitting area that overlooks the bay and there is plenty of seating. Staff was pretty nice and laid back.
author: Victor A.

description: They have jacked up the price and reduced the quantity. However the ice cream quality is still as good as before. Well that's expected if the rent of San Francisco is rising so rapidly
author: Julie L.

description: This place is my heaven!!! Smells delicious, tastes amazing and makes you feel like a kid again! I recommend the Nob Hill Chill, it's a hot fudge sundae in the form of a shake!!!!
author: Jennifer A.

description:
I stopped by here the last time I was in San Francisco and fell in love, so naturally it was on my list of places to visit this time around. Yummy desserts, as I remembered, but it's a pain to find a table.

The portions are perfect for sharing -- my boyfriend and I split the Domingo and left happy campers :)

Definitely check out the concierge for coupons!
author: Wendy T.

description:
After walking around Fisherman`s Wharf, I wanted to stop by Ghirardelli Square and get some ice cream.

While looking through the menu, I knew I wanted to get a banana sundae or a banana split, but the portion size sounded like so much (either had 2 or more scoops of ice cream). When we went to order, I had asked if they could do a banana sundae with only one scoop of ice cream and the guy nicely said that he could.

After placing your order, you walk past the cashier into the dining area. It`s very cute and looks like a revamped ice cream parlor. With 2 levels of dining area, seating is plenty.

When our Banana Sundae came out, it was huge! It was a good thing we didn`t get a regular sized banana sundae. Who would`ve thought one scoop of vanilla ice cream was going to be the size of a baby`s head! ^^ Haha.. it was more than enough for the both of us and it was so good! Bananas, hot fudge, chopped almonds, whipped cream, and a cherry on top. So yummy..
author: Chris T.

description:
this place is AMAZINGGGG! must stop here if you're ever visiting San Fran area. wide variety of chocolates to choose from so it makes gift shopping for friends a struggle & delicious ice cream to treat yourself.

it's kind of on the high price side but it's definitely worth it. 

i had the chocolate dipped waffle cone with two scoops of mint chocolate chip ice cream and the ghiradelli milk chocolate hot fudge, and it was the best thing that my taste buds ever ate!
author: Leah F.

description:
ive only had their icecream recently and it DOES taste good. i ordered some kind of hot fudge cookie sundae which costs around $8 but tasted really good! I LOVE THE HOT FUDGE.

this place can get really busy, but if you want to order to go, you can go upstairs and order. they have paper menus and i kept one for myself so i know which to get next time hahah.
author: Dee S.

description:
Pros:
We took the Duck Tour prior to visiting Ghirardeli and learned the story of how this place started...it's so inspirational!  I suggest sharing it with your kids.  Very touristy spot.  Definitely a Must-Do if you're visiting.  Located in a cute little plaza.  Mint flavored ice-cream is yummy:).  Great quality ice- cream.  I found a $1.00 off coupon on Yelp that I was able to use toward a sundae. 

Cons:
Very busy place. Expect to wait outside in a long line.  May have to stand inside for a bit after placing your order because tables are hard to come by.  If you have more than three people in your party you may not be able to sit together unless you wait a really long time.  Ice-cream is a bit pricey.  We paid $9.00+ for a two scoop sundae (note: I shared with my daughter and it was plenty). No restrooms inside!  Yikes!
author: Julie H.

description: Perfect chocolate place. Craving chocolate? Yup this is chocolate heaven. From shakes to hot chocolate to ice cream sundaes. Every thing is simply delicious and fresh. Staff is very friendly and this place is very clean. There is 2 location at the square. If one is packed with people go to the 2nd one. Plenty of room to sit. Well gotta go c you all later.
author: James S.

description:
All the Ghirardelli locations in SF are extremely packed on weekends.  This location has a takeout-only counter upstairs which is much faster than the seated areas downstairs.

All the hot chocolates are amazing!
author: Peter P.

description: Go for the  chocolate, stay for the ice cream.  You may not remember how to spell it's name but you will remember those delicious ice cream sundaes.
author: Tim C.

description: Customers just cranked through. Not a pleasant circumstance to enjoy our dessert with accompanying service.
author: Mohammed A.

description: Sundaes, big as hell, but holy hannah are they good. This place isn't just for tourists, and they know it, so they don't price gouge you. You get monster portion sizes of everything for a very reasonable price, and it's fantastic quality sweets too. Get a sundae in an on-the-spot-prepared waffle bowl. You'll thank me later. Oh, and you'll have to share it unless you just ran a half-marathon or something.
author: Danny C.

description: I was really looking forward to my chocolate milk shake that I always get at the ghirardelli  in Disneyland at California Adventure. I am allergic to nuts so at Disneyland they are very accommodating and make my stuff in the back with no nuts around. They type in the register nut allergy and automatically know what to do. Well this location in San Francisco doesn't do this. They don't accommodate people with nut allergies. The lady at the register just said you have to take this chance of coming in contact with nuts. Well that really isn't a good answer to me. If Disneyland Ghirardelli ALWAYS accommodates it should be here too. So my whole family enjoyed their ice cream sundaes and ice cream while I sat there. They all said it was good. Only complain is the nut allergy issue.
author: Tina R.

description:
Was it a good idea to have a Ghiradelli's sundae at midnight? Probably not. Unfortunately if you come at 11:50pm like me, you won't see much of the chocolate factory process in the back since they have started winding down the day and closing down, or have much time to shop the candy shop if you arrive late. 

However, the silver lining in the cloud was that I did miss all the tourists and typical crowdedness that normally ensues in the day time / afternoon. There was literally no wait. It's great that they open up till 12am though so I do have the option of getting a nice sugar fixing before I leave the city. Also, the sundae here really is the bomb so +1 to more silver lining - just make sure to share an order with a friend for a "healthy" (lawl, health) portioning tip!
author: Allie Y.

description: Was there this past December. It was super full, but it moved quickly. Very friendly staff. Very tasty chocolate ice cream but the waffle cone was of.
author: Lili M.

description:
Looking for a place to drown yourself in wonderful sugary and delicious treats..well then look no further, this place is it!

You can smell the sweet aroma of the sugary treats from a few blocks away..so just follow your nose here! As you walk through the door, a door man greets you with a smile and hands you a free piece of their chocolate. Amazing already! The place is small and is completely and neatly packed with all sorts of Ghirardelli chocolatey treats! If you are going to buy some, get the bag of assorted chocolates for $25, it's an awesome deal!

You really can't go in here and leave empty handed. Their chocolate is delicious, appropriately priced for a good chocolatier, and the staff is friendly. I would suggest avoiding this place on weekends, especially at peak day time hours because it gets slammed with tourists. Go next door to the chocolate shop and get some ice cream, grab a table outside, and enjoy it in the sunshine. If you live in SF or are just visiting, you have to check this place no matter what!
author: Akvile D.

description:
The only word to describe this place is...there are no words to adequately describe it. Here's my attempt: Unbelievable. Heaven. Amazing. Mind blowing... 

Wow. A must try.
author: N C.

description: Disappointed because it truly isn't the "factory" picture a big store filled with chocolate which you can get at any supermarket that sells this brand of chocolate.
author: Claudia A.

description:
Tourists wanting ice cream?

Take them here for a well known SF treat.  Ordered several of their Hot Caramel Sundaes and while they were busy consuming that, I was terribly disappointed in their quality of ice cream and costs associated with it.

I've actually had better real ice cream elsewhere.........this reminded me of Breyer's brand.  The Hot Caramel sundaes consisted of this layering method:

Lots of Caramel
1 scoop of vanilla ice cream
Lots of Caramel
Lots of whip cream
Dash of peanuts
1 Maraschino cherry

Total: $7.95 + tax

Honestly, highway thievery.  But the staff here are quick and efficient and do a great job.  If the higher cost is for their wages, then I'll toast that!
author: Miika M.

description:
My last meal on earth would be ice cream. I wake up thinking of it, go to bed dreaming of it and basically spend my day trying to figure out how to get more.

Thought the Gold rush Sundae would be 'too much' but who was I kidding? I had that down the hatch before the hubby could get a second bite. =)

It is the BEST ice cream concoction these taste buds have ever enjoyed and trust me...that's saying A LOT!

It's a MUST eat!
author: Sara M.

description: Super crowded, but well worth it.  I love this place. It's a must on most everyone's San Francisco trip and I can't wait to go back again when I travel back there.
author: J T.

description: It's fun, touristy, over-priced, but good chocolate and ice cream!!
author: Stephanie F.

description:
I always get the caramel sea salt hot chocolate. Its super decadent and rich. I normally get the large and take a few sips. I'll take it home and pour half into another cup, add milk, and voila! Now I have two hot chocolates! It's actually better that way because its a bit too sweet.

The service is kind of meh, but I don't mind because I know the people are probably super tired from all the people that come through.
author: Bianca W.

description: My friend and I split a Treasure Island sundae, and it was just way too much. The two of us ended up finishing less than half of it before giving up altogether. I've definitely had better sundaes, and I think after my experience here, it'll be a long while before I can give sundaes anywhere another try.
author: Kelly R.

description: Chocolate!!! The caramel sea salt sundae is delicious!! Prepare to wait a little while but it's worth it.
author: Rachel V.

description: The ice cream was wonderful. I shared a very nice sundae with my husband when it wasn't too crowded. You order when you come in, sit down, and they bring your order to your table. The whip cream and hot fudge were very delicious. I would not recommend the chocolate shop portion of the store. It's quite small, poorly arranged, and really nothing to see. You can find Ghirardelli chocolate all over the city (and probably for cheaper). I had an unfortunate experience in the chocolate shop where I was pushed waiting in line. There was a misunderstanding and a man with a young family tried to start a fight with me. Meanwhile, 4 women cut my husband in line. It ruined our whole experience and I have a disdain for the place now. I will never be back. If you don't like touristy places with lots of people, this place is missable.
author: Gina T.

description:
What's not to love? ...the tourists i guess.

Ghiradelli's is making some great hot fudge.  On our last trip to S.F. we made a real quick stop to try their classic hot fudge sundae.  We're glad we did because it was delicious.  We can easily say it's in our top 5 for sundaes.  

The fudge is gooooood, boarder line killer.  We swear if someone were to swallow some of this fudge and laughed at the same time they might end up in the hospital.  It's thick, smacks your teeth together and delivers a rich chocolaty goodness that most fudges don't have.

Everything in Ghiradelli's screams old fashion, which is great.  The square has a great atmosphere and a set of good street performers.  

The only negatives are that it's pretty busy and the place has a line of angry tourists.  Now we're not saying we're a regular there but there is a large handful of people in the world that make awful tourists.  They go to all these famous landmarks and are upset when they realize it's busy. Some people we're mad dogging us because they assumed we were cutting in line but were we actually trying to get around the line to do some shopping.  Thankfully there is nothing we like more then to  respond to disgruntle line goers that make under the breath comments :)

So yeah If you can deal with the tourists you should check this place out.  We recommend that fudge!
author: Trang H.

description: Really can't beat this tradition of chocolate! Can be a little pricy, but the quality is inherent.
author: Nathaniel F.

description:
So a brotha would love to consider himself an ice creamologist; well, in which case I kinda do lol. When it comes to ice cream, my grading on places can easily switch depending what places have to offer. Fair enough. So before get off into anything, here is how I grade the following places including this one:

1. Ghirardelli and Mitchell's (neck and neck in no particular order)
2. Ben and Jerry's 
3. Coldstones

Have not got a chance to try a few other places on my list like Swenson's or Fenton yet, even though I'm sure those are good and I will place them once I do, but this place here and Mitchell's is why really like their ice cream because of the styles and type of ice cream they have to offer. I'm an ice cream shake head on top of just being an ice cream head. The best thing about this place is getting their candy made into your shake. I encourage everyone to try the Banana Dark Chocolate Sea Salt Caramel shake, as well as the hot chocolate. You will cry on one try, and no I did not cry. Ben and Jerry's and Coldstones have their own things to offer, but something about this and Mitchell's is where its at. Never a problem with service and all that. Buy you some and try you some...

- Saucy MB
author: Saucy M.

description: It's chocolate, what else is there to say?  Very good chocolate I suppose.  For a touristy spot, we didn't have to wait long to order and get our stuff.  You do need to look for the ice cream shop with the large store, no wait.  The other one that people flock to has a little bit of a line, but it seemed to move quickly.  The choco dipped waffle cone was awesome.  Naturally you should expect to pay a lot.  One scoop is about $5.  It was a nice place to relax and refresh after walking around for a while.
author: Deb G.

description:
To go line was crazy. Cindy was terrible cashier. She clearly felt like her text was more important to finish before even greeting us as we are standing right in front of her register. the guys that were making all the order were great. Kept it going. Organization would be key. An extra body to explain to guests how the line forms or something would be helpful. 

Ice cream is always great. This experience just reinforced that ordering at the main restaurant and just getting a seat is more worth my time.
author: Kimberly M.

description: Great store!!! Such a shame that we didn't get to enjoy their dessert in the cafe. The line was long even at 10:30!
author: Denise C.

description:
This is such a fun place to be at.  I'd come here at least once a year with friends for the atmosphere and goooddd chocolate.  Sundaes here are a must try, but if you want something warm, go for the hot cocoa.   It's located near the water so it gets freezing cold if you have to wait in line outdoors, so come fully clothed!  There are plenty of fun places to visit around as well, so you can spend practically an entire day here.  

When I think of Ghirardelli, I think of a good time with friends chatting over amazing sweet treats!
author: Julie C.

description:
What place is open super late on a weeknight and isn't a bar or club? This place! We were in the area after visiting the Palace of Fine Arts and decided to grab a delicious treat before heading home.

Walking in, we had a short line at the counter, ordered a "Golden Gate," aka a banana split. Chocolate, vanilla, and strawberry ice cream sandwiched between two banana halves, topped with crushed pineapple, sliced strawberries, chocolate sauce, whipped cream, crushed almonds, and a maraschino cherry! It's a classic! I didn't feel like eating something heavy so late at night like a brownie sundae or a cookie sundae, so this was perfect!

After ordering at the counter and finding a seat (this place was crowded for a Thursday night!), we waited about 10 minutes for our ice cream... Yes, it was busy, but really? 10 minuets for ice cream? Oh well, we dove in and it was the perfect way to end a nice evening. The ice cream was creamy, the fruit toppings were refreshing, and the banana was perfectly ripe!

It's overpriced ice cream in a touristy area, but you just can't go wrong with this place! Between the two of us, it was the perfect amount without feeling too guilty.
author: Leana L.

description:
More of than not, I end up going to Ghiradelli square when I am in SF. Yes, it's a huge tourist trap, but on a nice sunny day - it's worth the hassle and wait to get some good ice cream w/their outrageously good dark chocolate syrup.

Best of all, every visitor gets a free (square) piece of chocolate!
I normally go to the take-out section, though waiting in such a small space does bother me a little it's a sacrifice worth making to avoid a super long wait.

Finding a seat usually isn't too hard although you do have to sort of stand around like vultures.
author: Willy W.

description:
It's such a tourist trap, but it's a SF thing to do.  There is always a line, but it goes pretty fast for the most part.

The caramel sea salt fudge sundae is pretty great though.  We placed our order at soon as you walk in.  Then you are given a tag for your order.  It is now up to you to find a place to sit in the parkour.  Since it is crowded most of the time, it's everyone for themselves.

We got lucky on a table as the people were just leaving as we walked by.  We waited only a few minutes for our order.  We were very disappointed because our sundaes came in plastic cups not in a sundae glass as expected.  The waiter told us they ran out of clean glass.  All the years they've been serving ice cream at this location, you'd think they have the system down so they can keep up with demand....guess not.

Never the less, the sundae still taste delicious. The sea salt compliments the sweetness of the fudge and caramel perfectly.  I love the Ghirardelli dark chocolate and sea salt caramel candy too.  Overall, it was a nice ending to a perfect day in SF.
author: G K.

description:
Best sundaes ever!!!!! You have to get a waffle bowl dipped in chocolate to get the full effect. It will cost you an arm and a leg but it's so worth it!!!!!
The midnight expresso is the best sundae in the world!!! Ghirafelli's coffee ice cream is really good...and all that hot fudge....mmmmmm
You have not lived until you've had one of these sundaes!
author: Ann C.

description:
Everytime I think of Ghirardelli Chocolate, I think of my BF and I. Why? Because it's one of those special places that we go to once in a while for a nice treat. 

Dont be intiminated by the lines out the door as they are usually long, but the wait goes by really quick. We usually get one item and share, each time being something different. The portions here are pretty big so sharing is definitely enough for us. 

When the weather is not too windy/chilly, we like to go down to Aquatic Park at night for a little walk. The views are nice.
author: M W.

description: Our first time at Ghirardelli Square so we had to get some hot chocolate. The place was super crowded and it was freezing (or at least for a San Diegan). I would say get a cup and share. My entire family was on. A sugar high for awhile.
author: Pharoeth E.

description:
It's hardcore touristy.

It's overpriced.

And I go for ice cream every single time I visit San Francisco.  The sundaes are huge and decadent.  The ice cream is great.  It's just one of those experiences that you KNOW is one big ripoff, but you are powerless to resist.
author: Frank F.

description: OMG! This is the best dark chocolate ice-cream I have had in my life. Worth every penny, their sundaes are so good and so huge, that it was a task to finish an entire one by myself. Surely a place great for families.
author: Sid J.

description:
Busy place that's why place is kinda dirty.  Around late night, it's pretty clean and less crowded.
Hot fudge yummmmmmm.  Me loves it!  Hot cocoa?  yup that too!
author: Claire J.

description:
Yummy ice cream, but it's just so expensive. 

Definitely share the sundaes because they're so sweet and large.
author: Kathy L.

description: I like it simple... Ghirardelli hot fudge sundae is all a girl can ever ask for! this amazing spot will put a smile on your face, whether your a local or a tourist. the caramel latte is pretty good on a cool night after that yummy sundae!
author: Ann T.

description:
Ghirardelli square isn't actually a square devoted to chocolate or anything, in fact Ghirardelli chocolate isn't even produced in San Francisco anymore. The square does however have two Ghirardelli chocolate shops offering all of their chocolates as well as ice cream. Many people come here for the ice cream, which is very good and the portions are generous but is only available in a handful of  common flavors and is pretty expensive for non homemade ice cream. The square was originally home to the Ghirardelli chocolate factory but is now home to a number of stores and eateries. The area surrounding the square is one of the most beautiful and best maintained parks in the city. It features the beginning of the world famous Hyde St cable car line, views of the Golden Gate Bridge, a large lawn, a small beach area, and is blocks from the Fisherman's Wharf area.
 
Here is some more information on Ghirardelli:
 
Domenico Ghirardelli was born in Italy in 1817 and worked under a confectioner in Genoa when he was very young. In his 20s he left for South America and became a coffee and chocolate merchant. Lured by the gold rushes, Ghirardelli moved to California in 1849 and opened up a general store (which of course included chocolate). By 1852 Ghirardelli opened his first chocolate factory which changed spots a number of times before ending up at the factory at North Point St in San Francisco in 1895. The Ghirardelli company was sold in the 1960s and was moved to San Leandro, CA. The factory building was then sold and opened up in 1964 as a square featuring the format you see today with a number of shops and restaurants.
author: Matt E.

description:
Must do for out of town visitors
Great chocolate and ice cream
Assembly line ordering, crowded
Efficient servers
Retail chocolate on way out
A little on the spendy side, but this is San Francisco
author: Rosquete B.

description: Ice cream is great, chocolate is great...and so are free samples. Need I say more?
author: Michelle K.

description:
Ghirardelli Chocolate shop and ice cream parlor is another must visit in San Francisco. I have heard and read that the line can be long. As far as the ice cream parlor, it does not take that many people to form a line. Right when you step in you will see a counter with two registers. 

The prices are on the high end but what isn't in San Francisco?!?! 

I had the warm brownie sundae. It was a pretty good sundae. It did get too messy. Having a warm brownie at the bottom melted the ice cream quicker.

While it is expensive it still is worth the visit; especially if it is your first time in San Francisco.
author: Queen Claire B.

description:
MMM CHOCOLATE!! My family usually hits all the typical touristy spots in SF when we have out of town guests, and this place has recently joined the list bc of its proximity to Pier39 :]

After all the walking, who can resist their free samples?? They're little quadrilaterals of pure heaven... haha. So this time I stopped by after a quick walk through the 2010 Chocolate Festival. I arrived late to the festival and the parking meter was running out of time (I later figured out it was FREE. Either that or every meter in SF decided to flash 'expired' at the same time) and to make the trip seem worthwhile, I had to grab something sweet from the to-go side of this place. 

I split a Domingo w/ my food crazed friend Jon (I've never seen him turn down food... not that I can recall...) and it was DELICIOUSSS. I usually don't really like sundaes, I prefer my ice cream plain and solid, not the icky melted mess that gets everywhere, but this one was pure amazing. We handed it back and forth as we trekked back to the car and the layers of vanilla and gooey fudge with slices of banana was perfect. 

Only downsides: the place was super packed (yes, there was a festival, but I usually see a line out the door to get a seat on normal days), and the layout of the to-go area made no sense. There were 3-4 registers facing two different directions, there was hardly any place to line up, and once you order you wait by the door for them to call your name. Being next to the door, people are constantly pushing by trying to get in, and its quite chaotic. Definitely almost got stepped on / elbowed multiple times here. GRR. :[ I'd def want to come back and enjoy something warm when winter rolls around though.
author: Christine L.

description:
When you feel like spending a little more money on fancier ice cream, this is the place to be!!

It's about 7 dollars for a sundae and totally worth it.  Whipped cream, syrup, and ice cream heavennn.

One day when I can get enough people to split with me so I don't gain 4 pounds, I will try the Earthquake.  That's like the ultimate of the ultimate.  It's like the 5 pound burger at burger joints.
author: Vivian H.

description: The best hot chocolate I have ever had. The service was very good and quick. The gift shop it is located in is nice, but unfortunately does not have all the Ghirardelli products in stock so I had to order a gift box online.
author: Edward R.

description: Yummy sundae for sure, really rich in every flavor. Price is high, so it's definitely a treat but one you want to experience. I'd go back.
author: Nicole S.

description: Be prepared for chaos and lines - if in SF a must "do" as a tourist.  Fantastic chocolate ice cream - shakes too - i had fab cheery vanilla with dark chocolate hot fudge.  Bit skimpy on sauce but they were happy to add more.  If you choose to sit you can eat off of glass and real silverware or if you get it to go sit outside and people watch.  I had to follow up on our order - we waited 20 minutes but it was because they gad to get one of the sherbet flavors they ran out of but they then forgot our entire order.  So crowded impossible to shop in the chocolate store area.   Its super pricey - about $10 per person.
author: Moab E.

description:
HOT days are quite rare in the Bay, especially this "summer." Today it was just all about enjoying the sun after work. 

I ended up passing up AT&T Park & Pier 39. There on Beach St. is a smaller version of Ghirardelli's ice cream shop. Zero tourists, friendly staff, and I needed a sugar fix. Got myself a hot fudge sundae in a chocolate dipped waffle bowl. Sure, it's just vanilla ice cream, hot fudge, whipped cream and almonds (no cherry, pls.) But who cares? I don't! I think Ghirardelli has got good fudge. It's thick, creamy and not too sweet. 

At first, I was not happy with that waffle bowl. It's dipped in chocolate so it was pretty hard to break into pieces. But once I was done with it, it was pretty good. Good enough to eat by itself, in fact.
author: S Y.

description: Slow service, stingy with the hot fudge, way too crowded and expensive - however, it is a delicious landmark and worth going on rare occasions.
author: Rebecca G.

description:
Everbody knows how delicious Ghirarrdelli is, and of course, this place is amazing.  You step in, and they are handing out samples of chocolate.  Bonus points already!  They have a huge selection of sundaes and other desserts to choose from in which all are delicious and rich.  You might even need a friend or 2 to finish these.

Also, you can buy exclusive chocolates that are not sold in your local candy or grocery stores.  I stocked on some "special flavors" like creme brulee, cinnamon, etc.

I've been a here few times when I come to visit Cali.  Always a delight to come here.
author: Elise T.

description:
A well known tourist destination, Ghirardelli Square offers ice cream sundaes, chocolates of all sorts, and a variety of other stores. The Ghirardelli ice cream shop in particular is a big attraction.  My high school senior class even had a "senior ice cream night" at this very place! You can order the Earthquake - a sundae with 8 scoops and 8 toppings to share with friends and family. Although there is a lot of seating, it can still be difficult to find a chair and table amongst all the tourists, locals, and visitors.

I come here every so often for an ice cream sundae. I would rate it higher if it wasn't priced so high at $8+ for a sundae! With amazing ice cream stores like Bi-Rites, Humphrey's, and Mitchell's... Ghirardelli's quality and price just doesn't do it for me. I had a butterscotch ice cream sundae last week and couldn't handle the sugar :) but i'm sure there are many people who would enjoy it immensely.

I still think it's a must for visitors. Take a photo by the brightly lit sign and enjoy one of their sweet concoctions.
author: Samantha L.

description:
I grew up on Ghirardelli chocolate, this was where we celebrated our birthdays, had parties or even just a family night out. This year for my youngest brother's bday, we did the usual! We had just finished up a somewhat stressful dinner at Cafe Divine. When we got to Ghirardelli square, we got the yummy hazelnut chocolate, after ordering, we sat down to chat. 

It was taking longer then usual but we were just enjoying ourselves so that was okay. The problem arised when the ice cream came. The whole thing was melted by the time she set it down on the table. We pointed this out to the server and she said it was a little melted. I said, it's more like a puddle. My brother later pointed out that we ordered banana split and there wasn't any banana in it. I went to the ice cream station to figure out what happened. 

The server told us it was the chocolate and strawberry that melted so I just asked her to bring out new scoops of other flavors. When she came out with the other, we watched it melt before out eyes, she did too because when she put it down, it turned into a puddle. (Her expression was priceless) She apologized again, her manager came out  and apologize and told us the freezer was broken. She said they only have Vanilla left. I was like VANILLLA URGGRGGRGRGRG, she ended up giving us a refund and a few scoops of vanilla ice cream (I'm guessing they refunded a lot of people) but throughout the whole thing, the manager and the staff were very polite and handled it very well. Emergencies happen, no problem.
author: Tiff W.

description: I love chocolate! I got some ice cream though. I got their cookies and cream and it was soooo good! I love ice cream! It was creamy and not too sweet! I love ghiradelli chocolates too but didn't buy any because I could get that at any grocery store.
author: Shirley K.

description: Yummmy best ice cream sundae and chocolate bars and cocoa. Such a great stop. Line is long but worth it
author: Renee G.

description: Being that there is so much to see in San Francisco, Ghirardelli was on the list of if there's time stops. Fortunately my lil one insisted on riding the Powell cable car and the driver suggested it. It was freezing so we opted for hot chocolate instead of ice cream. It was the best hot chocolate I've ever had. Even the whipped cream was delicious. My kids loved it. They got pretty chocolate wasted. The hot chocolate was smooth and thick. Very creamy and sweet. A hot cup of amazing. Hopefully on our next trip out we can try the ice cream.
author: Yvonne S.

description:
Over the past few years, I've seen the portion size of their sundaes and to-go cup sizes shrink, but this location of Ghirardelli has brought so many good memories to my family and me that I just can't give them any less than 4 stars. Every time my family comes to visit me in Northern California, we never fail to visit Ghirardelli at least once. Yes, the lines are long, and yes, at $8-10 a sundae, the prices are quite ridiculous, but a trip to SF just isn't complete without a visit to Ghirardelli Square.

My family usually gets the World Famous Hot Fudge Sundae, but I'm more of a mint chocolate chip and dark chocolate type of girl so my go-to is the Mint Bliss. They tend to switch up their other sundaes with the seasons, but those two are some of the few sundaes that they serve year-round.

They've opened up a few other locations within the square, as their main one tends to get very crowded during the weekends and late evenings, but my family still likes visiting the original location, regardless of the crowd. During their busiest days, they usually open up the counter upstairs, so those days, we just take our sundaes to-go and eat them outside their shop. We've noticed that the employees tend to be more generous with the serving sizes for to-go orders too, so we never mind taking our sundaes to-go. They also tend to give larger scoops to those who order non-vanilla ice cream sundaes (like any of their Intense Dark Sundaes that use mint chocolate chip or espresso chip ice cream). I've noticed that my Mint Bliss Sundae always ends up towering over everyone else's World Famous because the employees aren't as afraid of running out of their other flavors as they are with the vanilla ice cream.
author: Gaby W.

description:
So touristy but so fun. If you have at least four good eaters in your party, go for the Earthquake Sundae. It's a chunk of change at $34.95 but it's quite an experience and has the side benefit of being really delicious. 

It comes with eight scoops of ice cream of your choice, eight toppings of your choice and it's finished with fresh bananas, whipped cream, chopped almonds, decadent chocolate chips and cherries. It's a sight to see!

Downstairs is counter service (with delivery to your table) and you get to see how the chocolate is roasted, processed etc. You also get to watch them make their fresh cones.

Upstairs (same prices) seems mostly for take out but they have a few tables as well.
author: Sandy D.

description: Yummy cold treat on a beautiful San Francisco day! Got a hot fudge sundae which was yummy. It's always busy so just be patient for a seat and them to deliver it to you!! :)
author: Katlin V.

description: Really rich desserts! And, as my fellow Yelpers note, very touristy. Whenever some of my friends come from overseas, I always take them to SF, and this is a frequent stop. Still, I don't mind coming here since they give out free samples and tend to my sweet tooth as well!
author: Matt M.

description:
It is pricey but they have great and speedy service. Even when it is busy. Plus they definitely deliver on quality! The strike it rich was delish!!!
