But if you want to gnaw on your cookie and enjoy a crunchy outside and incredibly dense chewy inside, GET THIS COOKIE, you're in for a treat. Also get a glass of milk cause you're gonna need it. I take days to eat it. Yes, its that big.

The rest of the place I'd give 2 stars, because it is touristy as hell, you can buy their chocolate squares anywhere, and not only is the ice cream shop service slow as hell, what comes out to you is not very good either. As other reviewers have mentioned, the only reason to spend any money at their chocolate shop is if you're getting an SF-themed gift for someone (cable-car chocolates or chocolates in an SF tin). There's really nothing particularly special about this place otherwise.
author: M S.

description: I love love LOVE ghirardelli chocolate. I grew up near Hershey, Pennsylvania, but I have always liked Ghirardelli better. I tried the hot chocolate and it was soooo good, but really rich. I would suggest sharing this with someone if you're not a germ freak. Even the smaller size was too much. Make sure you go into the store on the lower level, they give free samples :)
author: Chantelle C.

description:
Mmmmm Goldrush sundae!
 I finished up my touristy day in San Francisco with an amazing sundae at Ghirardelli.  I'm a peanut butter and chocolate fiend so this was the best sundae I've ever had! Warm gooey chocolate mixed with peanut butter. Heck yeah!
author: Allegra I.

description:
Why are there two locations in the square? One for ice cream sundaes and another for hot chocolates? I personally went to the one far in the back for some "must-have" hot chocolate. I got that and the salt caramel hot chocolate with whipped cream. First off, the hot chocolate is rich and thick, but super hyped. $5 for an 8 oz cup. Seriously that is more than Starbucks charges for a venti frappucino. In addition, the salt caramel "hot" chocolate wasn't hot. It was lukewarm and the whipped cream melted all in the drink leaving glistening fat globs on the surface. All for another $5.

I wouldn't with the drinks. Rather, just walk around and enjoy the ambiance. Then save your $$ for a nicer dinner.
author: Susan D.

description:
Since moving to San Francisco, my husband has been wanting a hot fudge peanut butter sundae from Ghiradelli Square. We were in the area a few times, but because it's a tourist spot, the line was too crazy. However, we recently went late on a Saturday, and the line was manageable and fast moving.

My husband ordered the peanut butter hot fudge sundae. His exact words were "it was everything he expected" but "not everything he wished for." He enjoyed the chocolate and peanut butter, and it hit the spot for him. However, he wished there was more ice cream, and he wanted the sauces to be warmer. I think his star rating would be in the 3 or 4 realm.

However, this review is based on my experience. First, I will add the caveat that I am pretty sensitive to processed food. After about five bites of my sundae, my stomach started to revolt, and I had to stop eating. As for the taste/etc. of the sundae (before I stopped), the whipped cream tasted like sweet cardboard, there was too little ice cream (and it was not good quality ice cream), and the chocolate sauce in my sundae was congealed and overpowering.

Give me homemade ice cream at a local shop any day.
author: Stephanie S.

description: Boyfriend and I split a $9 sundae. It was good, but not worth the money. I'm still glad that I went because it's a good tourist spot. They show you first hand how the chocolate is made, which is really cool. There's also a chocolate store that sells the same basic varieties of chocolate that you can buy at the grocery store, at a significant mark up. Don't let it fool you, there's better chocolate out there.
author: Dar E.

description:
I have very fond memories here. I won't get all nostalgic on you but I will say that I've had some fantastic times relaxing, chatting and dating over their superior hot fudge sundaes. 

It MUST be the fudge. I start to salivate just thinking about its amazingness. I can eat my weight in the stuff. Sometimes when I order I say, "light on the ice cream, please... and extra fudge." It's not the most flattering request but whatever, I get over that quickly when it plops down in front of me at the table.
author: Julia N.

description: Portions are big enough to share. It was very busy and service was less than welcoming. Their location at the bottom of the hill was less crowded. Kid menu offers generous portions and variety. Recommend checking that.
author: Karem P.

description: I've been coming here to get my sweet tooth fix, for over 15 years now. Every time I come to the Bay Area, I always make a stop to Ghirardelli. This time around I bought a ton of bars and three bags of squares. I bought a lot of the darker chocolate, since my dad really likes it, and a few specialty bars for myself. Although, this is a big time tourist attraction, I recommend coming here just to pick up a few item and then leave unless you want to hang out with the tourists.
author: Jim A.

description: The chocolate coffees are extremely thick, rich and tasty.  There was/is also a promotion for chocolate candies: Buy 4, get 1 free. There's also free additional creamy chocolate samples as you enter the door.
author: Cathaleya C.

description: Of course you have to come if you're in the Bay area, it's where chocolate and sweets are born. You have the shop and the cafe right next to each other. We come for the sundaes. The ice cream is smooth, the fudge is a perfect chocolatey and gooey.
author: Stephanie Y.

description: Been a few times over the years while playing tourist in the area and always pleased with my ice cream dessert.  Love the free sample chocolates too especially the seasonal flavors in the fall/winter.  It's a bit pricy but that's expected in a tourist area and there's ALWAYS a line even on cold SF days and nights.  Forget about trying to park nearby its always crowded so use a garage or paid parking lot and take the hike up the hill to enjoy your treat.
author: Mary E.

description: I try not to go to the more "touristy" eatery's, but unfortunately I fell for this one! I love ice cream, so I was at Ghirardelli Square during my visit to San Fran, and by seeing the line I figured it had to be pretty good! However, I was disappointed! For a price of $8.00 for a brownie sundae, I was expecting something delicious, but my brownie was gross and my ice cream was very airy and was about the same quality as dreyers, but for a much higher price! The one good thing was service was very friendly.
author: Addie K.

description: Cute touristy spot. Unfortunately everything may contain peanuts so my son couldn't try anything due to his allergy. Thus, turning us away. That and the extensive line that wrapped out the door.
author: Jessica R.

description: oh... i hate that i'm lactose intolerant.. but i'll deal with the aftermath to have the ice cream sundaes during hot days... and delicious hot chocolate during the fall and winter months!
author: Angel D.

description: Sundaes are very good but $10???  I had to take out a second mortgage to buy sundaes for a family of five. Good ice cream and good hot fudge but way, way overpriced.
author: Al N.

description: Yum!  How can you go wrong here?  It's a magical land of chocolate, like every dream I've ever had!  You can purchase all kind of chocolates here, from chocolate bars, chocolate chips, hot chocolate mixes, etc, as well as getting frozen chocolately drinks and ice cream.  Although I'm sure this place is tourist central, I being a tourist am not bothered by that fact.  I would happily revisit this place every time I'm in San Francisco.  I mean, you can't go wrong with chocolate and ice cream!  MMMMMMM!!
author: Victoria K.

description:
So...I ordered a brownie sundae last time and it was horrible.  It sounded SO good on the menu and I was really disappointed when I finally got it.  This time I ordered a mint something-or-other in the dark chocolate section.  I got some fudgy stuff with a scoop of chocolate ice cream on top of it, and then a scoop of mint chip on top of that.

First Bite...So Good!  So Good!
Bite.  Bite.  Bite.  Bite.
Yum!
Bite.  Bite.  Bite.  Bite.
Oh...the fudge is on the bottom!
Bite.  Bite.  Bite.  Bite.
How much more of this is left?
Bite.  Bite.  Bite.  Bite.
OK...I'm only eating this for the starving children in Africa.
Bite.  Bite.  Bite.  Bite.
I never want to eat chocolate again.

So...yeah, it was really good but WAY too much for one person!  My dining companions had a banana split, a brownie sundae, and a banana sundae that were all mediocre.

My stomach hurts!  Majorly!  Too much ice cream!  I almost suggested Bombay ice cream...oh WHY didn't I suggest Bombay ice cream?
author: PrincessPeac H.

description:
There is something about visiting the ice cream shop in SF.  I always feel like I have to go when I'm visiting SF.  For about $10 we had the traditional hot fudge sundae in a chocolate dipped waffle bowl.  What's not to like?  

Be sure to go through the chocolate retail section, they pass out their chocolate squares!  Yum!
author: Natalie B.

description:
Warm. Brownie. Sundae.

(Far superior to the Cookie Bottom Sundae, by the way: the cookies are dry, not warm or freshly baked). As a child, this place was probably near the top of my "favorite places" list, with a 5-billion-star rating. However, now that I'm older and wiser and more experienced in the ways of the world (and in a tempestuous affair with Godiva Chocolate), my tastes have changed a little. Still, Ghirardelli's in-store treats are always magical. Even the basic ice cream & waffle cone is devastatingly delicious. Just thinking about it makes my stomach hurt. 

In the best, most scrumptious way possible, of course.
author: Sam S.

description:
I am not really a fan of sweets and general. Went sight seeing with my new nikon d300 DSLR and came down to take a seat and rest. I was ordered up a milk chocolate hot fudge sunday. I let it sit for a sec while I looked at my pics for the day. 

First impression of my first bite was damn this is pretty damn good. Its sweet but not overpowering, and it what it really has going for it is that its super creamy. If you like vanilla and chocolate flavors, they got you covered. I would rate this place up there with fentons and higher than coldstone for sure.
author: chris c.

description: Heavier than store bought ice cream. I felt so bad finishing up a two scoop waffle cone. One scoop is plenty.
author: Steven T.

description:
Best damn coffee ice cream Ive had, but for ordering 2 scoops and getting one thats melted?

Fast service but we did have one order that was "misplaced".

Get your chocolate on here and be done with it.


nyah.....
author: Mike F.

description: A definite stop over while you are sightseeing.  Come at night when everything is nicely lit up and the crowds have departed.
author: Marco D.

description:
i have hit this shop numerous times over the last twenty years, and i have always, always dug the choco-shop and the malt shop. there's a nice chocolate demonstration history thingie, and the lot validates for the first hour...... the shop is two level, and both have always been busy as lomg as i can remember.

for a period of time, ghiradelli shops popped up all over, including one in my beloved pasadena, but, alas, common sense prevailed over the multi-plex expansion, and ghiradelli was once again relegated to a once a year or two love affair, as it should be.

this year we rocked a double chocolate malt, a strawberry shake, and a root beer float. oh, baby! ice cream to die for, and like see's candy, they always hit you with a freebie demo to kick your chocolate buzz into motion.
author: Tony B.

description:
tourist or not... Ghirardelli is a must. Not just the chocolate, the ice creams! Yum!. first of all if you have enough people... you HAVE to get the Earthquake. it's a San Francisco classic. it's 8 scoops of ice cream and all the toppings. it's about $30. i've done it with 3 people.

this weekend i went with just my boyfriend. we shared the banana hot fudge sundae. there's nothing i can say that's bad about this place because you can't go wrong with anything you get.

always lots of people, but service is fast.
author: Nancy F.

description:
What can I say? It's the fuckin Ghirardelli Chocolate Factory; an iconic part of San Francisco that every one who come here just has to visit. Sure, it's busy all the time, and the pricing is a little ridiculous, but you just have to go. I live in the East Bay, and yesterday was the first time I've haven't been in probably 10 years, but I'm really glad I went.

My sister and I ordered the Famous Sundae, which seemed like the most classically delicious way to go. It was. It was a little small for two people, but it certainly satisfied. The service was a lot quicker than I expected too.
author: Christopher B.

description:
I'm starting to take on a touristy approach to SF even though I've lived here for nearly 10 years and yesterday it was visiting twin peaks (and seeing 2 rainbows) and coit tower at night. After lunch, I was craving ice cream of some sort and since it was a Tuesday, I knew parking would be a cinch at Ghiradelli Square. 

I didn't have any chocolate on Valentine's Day...in fact, I didn't have anything remotely valentine's-y that day so I guess I could say I made up for it with a warm brownie sundae here after the fact. 

For $9.22 (price with tax), it was a pricey sundae but it was pretty good. The hot fudge melted some of the ice cream into vanilla soup. As the fudge cooled, it became thick like peanut butter (hmm...now I'm curious about trying their hot fudge peanut butter sundae) and the brownie was just as decadent. Midway through the eating, I started thinking "oh god, this is way too much chocolate for me! I hate chocolate!" and I declared to the boy toy that I'm never eating that again.

Well, today's a new day and I'm craving that thing again like mad and I promise I won't make any premature declarations this time around.
author: kristin e.

description:
After a dinner in the city, my friends and i or my boyfriend and i usually make a stop to the ice cream bar at ghirardelli square.

My usual is the Domingo. Dreyers vanilla ice cream, ghirardelli fudge, and a banana. It's so WONDERFUL! simple and good. Alot of their ice cream creations are just delicious. yummy!
Their fudge they use from their chocolate is amazing. 

It's always a good time to stop by here and have ice cream with your friends. After we usually just walk down towards the pier and nearby park and enjoy san francisco.
author: Julie B.

description:
I came here after having dinner in the area. I was so excited to try out one of their famous sundaes after reading about it. Unfortunately, my sundae came out all melted. My order didn't even take that long to come out, but it was all soup as soon as I dipped my spoon in it. I had to eat the top part really quickly because my ice cream was dripping down the bowl every time I dipped my spoon in. Now I have a very high tolerance for sweets. I love sugary anything and I'm the type of person who could eat dessert before a meal or replace my actual meal with dessert, but this sundae was too much even for me. Also overpriced as well. As soon as I ate half of it, I couldn't go any further anymore because I felt so nauseous. I couldn't even move. This dessert is not worth the calories or the sad feeling of guilt the morning after. After consuming this last night, I am riding out a chocolate chocolate hangover because of this sugar bomb from last night. Save your money unless you like ice-cream soup and aching arteries! I'd take the Dazzler from Haagen Daz's over this mess and it costs less and comes to you not melted.

1* for being open until midnight on Fridays
1* for the variety of chocolate goodies in the adjoining store
author: Nancy C.

description:
i can't justify in paying 10+ dollars for a dessert where you only get a max of 5 spoons out of it because they just melt so darn fast... (thats 2 dollars a bite!!!! haha) 

they should freeze the ice cream realllllllllllly cold and then pour the hot fudge so it doesn't melt it as fast.. 

i really liked the banana split before.. but i just didnt think it was worth digging around the melted ice cream for some actual ice cream left.. 

oh well better for my waistline
author: JUDY L.

description:
Here's a secret for locals (or smart Yelpers) - there is a cafe right near the entrance to Ghirardelli Square.  It is typically packed with people lining up out the door.  If you walk across the square there is another cafe (exactly the same if I'm correct) that has almost zero line at any given time.  
Walk across the square people.
Their mochas are rich and delicious, but man, I wish I had seen the poster for their shakes with blended up bits of flavored Ghirardelli squares in them before I ordered.  YUM.
author: Jennifer D.

description:
Mmmmmmmmmmmmmmmm!  BEST HOT FUDGE in the world!  Made with melted Ghirardelli dark chocolate... ugh, so good!

I don't care about the long wait, the tourists, or anything else - when I'm eating my mint chocolate chip ice cream smothered in hot fudge and whipped cream, the rest of the world just melts away...
author: Laura W.

description:
5 *'s for the chocolate!!!

-5*'s for the weight ive gained!!!


i bought about $100 worth of chocolate.... i ate all of it in less than a month.... OMG!!! i am still suffering from the weight gain... i cant walk... and cant breathe... but man... it was GOODD... 

me, myself , and all the other girls in this world loves chocolates... so if you were to do something bad to me.................

GHIRARDELLI would be JUST the thing to make me feel better~ hehhe
author: Eunji y.

description:
I shared a nice hot fudge sundae with my girlfriend here. We decided on dark chocolate fudge with a chocolate dipped waffle bowl. I enjoyed the fudge (which wasn't really hot, but that's okay). She liked the bowl better. Given the price (~$9), I expected more ice cream, but maybe I'm spoiled by Fenton's.

Summary: 3.5/5 stars rounded up
+Good sundae, great chocolate
+Fast service
-Small portions for what you pay for
author: Daniel M.

description:
$6.50 for a regular sized peanut butter chocolate milk shake that was grainy......................

20 minutes standing in line trying not to blend in with the tourists........... 

another 10 minutes waiting while the new trainee made my horrible milk shake.............. 

All this makes for a very pissy Jen...................
author: Jen D.

description:
Dear Chocolate Sample Distributor,
Please keep rotating your position for my fear of being recognized. Thank you for your free samples. Although dangerous... they keep my 1st week of the month happy (ladies, you know).

Yes, true... Strictly tourist territory. But I work across the street and am a regular. In fact I am not a regular customer, but a regular sampler.

I get bumped, pushed, and blocked, all to get to my free chocolate sample. Soon I'll venture from free sample to actually buying a sundae. They look delish!
author: Dee C.

description: I don't eat sweets too much so I wasn't too crazy about seeing so much chocolate. I walked into the ice cream shop and ordered the hot chocolate with caramel sea salt and the butter pecan ice cream. I fig just simple stuff. Sipped into some of the hot choc and tasted the bits of caramel sea salt...oh man, that was great! The choc wasn't too sweet. It was nice and light. The caramel sea salt just added a nice contrast. It went really well together. I do love my salt though. Then took a bit of my butter pecan ice cream....in love! I know it's just butter pecan but it's the best I've tasted. It wasn't too sweet and the ice cream had a nice soft texture so it just melted in your mouth.
author: Meilani M.

description: We use to go there many years ago, decided to relive our ice cream outings memory, and it was a big disappointment. Ordered the cable car sundae, it had more whipping cream foam than ice cream. I had to look really hard to see if I could find the fudge, maybe was just max 2 teaspoons in the whole dish, in the past it use to be at least 4 tablespoons, there was also only 1 tsp of chopped almonds, when we had much more in the past. Disappointed, we walked around the plaza and saw their new store, curiosity took us to the sundae bar, standing there for a few minutes, we could observe the inconsistency in the preparation, one the servers preparing the same cable car, had ice cream balls twice the size of ours and generously poured fudge on the sides and chopped nuts. I am not sure if we will go back, as the quality is no longer there.
author: jane l.

description:
every time i come to san fran, this is one of the places that sticks out in my mind. since i was a little kid.
it's just overwhelmingly full of chocolate in every possible way you could want chocolate. can it get much better than that?

their dark chocolate almond clusters are probably as close to heaven as you'll ever get.
author: Amanda S.

description: When you want the best $4.00 hot chocolate in the city just go the place everyone has and vows never to go on summer weekends...  But on this cold December Tuesday there were no lines, no wait and no one keeping me from mainlining the creamy chocolate nectar into my veins.  Now if I could only figure out a way to not scare the tourists while feeding my insane chocolate addiction.
author: Scott S.

description: Very touristy, but it's nice to visit once in a while.  I love the atmosphere, but most of all, the Presidio Passion sundae...the best sundae ever created.  The chocolate in that sundae is like nothing like I've ever tasted...rich, perfectly sweet...it's hard to describe.  If you live anywhere near Ghirardelli Square, go...now.
author: Basim Z.

description: You can't miss with rich chocolate and creamy ice cream.  Ghirardelli Ice Cream and Chocolate Shop has so many ways to enjoy chocolate!  Gotta go there!
author: Paul M.

description: Super delicious sundaes! They are really big and will keep you full for a really long time! The employee when we first arrived to order was extremely rude! I had a hard time hearing her through the loud surroundings and she was giving me really bad attitude because she had to repeat herself. She had a strong accent and I was being really polite trying to make out what she was trying to say. I would give this place more stars if the service was not so bad!
author: Shannyn W.

description:
Chocolate is DEFINITELY a great substitute for a man.

Who need penis when you have delicious, creamy, melt-in-your-mouth chocolate!!!

Even the mocha latte tastes heavenly...you don't really taste the espresso but who cares!

My new boyfriend's name is Chocolate. 
He's HOT!!!!!
author: Jay H.

description:
Okay honestly. Seriously. Chocolate heaven! 
Downfall - LONG line & LONG wait for open seats at times. 

Nevertheless, the hot fudge sundae is to die for. The fudge is warm & perfectly sticky. Today I tried this "earthquake" thing with some friends & wow, I swear - my spoon couldn't stop reaching for all those different types of ice creams. Personal faves - mint chocolate chip & cookies 'n cream. It was only when all the ice cream was melted did the "earthquake" look unappetizing. Still, I was definitely satisfied. I mean, my friend on the drive home..let's just say she was so full after ghirardelli's that she had to change from tight jeans into loose shorts.
author: Steph W.

description:
This is a big tourist spot, but I love it.  I have lots of fond memories here.  I always get a banana split, strawberry ice cream, and of course coffee.  :D

Recently I tried their blueberry cheesecake ice cream.  With coffee of course.  Devoured it under the rain in the gazebo.  What a luxury...sweets, coffee, a view, and the calm of sprinkles falling from the sky.
author: Jenny K.

description:
I have a secret for you:

Trader Joes uses Ghirardelli chocolate in a lot of their goodies -- like the mint disks and the huge hunks of chocolate (and it's wayyy cheaper)

Shhh, don't tell anyone.
author: Ali L.

description: Love love love the ice cream there!! You will have to try it!! The chocolate there alone was just average, but the ice cream, OMG, you cannot miss it!!!
author: Jojo L.

description:
This place was so busy when I came here. So if you plan on getting some chocolates or ice cream, plan to stay awhile. Oh and have someone grab a table outside because the indoor eating area is crazy packed as well. 

I ordered there hot fudge sundae cuz I mean, it's a tourist attraction right?! So why not?? The lady who took my order was kind of rude though I can understand she felt rushed because of all the people, but she charged me almost $9 for the sundae! Wheni asked her why it was so much for a small, she said it's because she keyed in a large and if i wanted to get a small i would have to seek her manager somewhere in the store to get a dollar and some change back. W/e I took the large. 

Chocolate was great in the sundae. I tossed the ice cream and whipped cream, just wanted the chocolaty goodness.
author: Diana V.

description:
Oh Emm Gee!!!!  Who ever thought of making chocolate is an effin genius...above all Ghirardelli chocolate.  Right there next to diamonds being a girl's best friend Chocolate is riiiiight there next to them....acutally diamonds INSIDE a box of chocolates is a brilliant idea!!  Well that is of course if your not allergic to chocolate...if so, that sucks for you BIG time because it is goooood!  I could literally spend an hour in this store.  

Ghirardelli Chocolate.....I don't care what anyone says I give you 5 whole stars :)
author: ChaCha F.

description: Hot chocolate on a cold day..... mmmmmm.  The friends we took scarfed down their sundae in a min after hitting the table. Of course they were waiting on me because I was savoring every sip.
author: Eugene P.

description: A visit to San Francisco is not complete without a World Famous Sundae from Ghiradelli! I always get the mint chip ice cream sundae. The sundaes are huge. My husband loves the shakes. I also love their chocolate bars. The new bars with strawberry are wonderful. I also like the raspberry and dark chocolate mint. They have 3 locations at Ghiradelli Square so if the main one is really busy, try the one at the back of the plaza upstairs or the one downstairs!
author: Susan M.

description:
Food: Satisfies the sweet tooth
Service: Has to be reasonably quick for the lines of tourists
Price: Decent considering the tourist attraction

They have heaping sundaes in the $7-$8 range with thick syrups and delicious scoops of ice cream. And they always top it with a delectable complementary flavored Ghirardelli chocolate square.

I've never been disappointed here with the desserts. 

The attached retail store is, as expected, overpriced. You're better off buying the squares at a grocery store for cheaper. Bed Bath and Beyond (interesting enough) sometimes has these fire sales on seasonal flavors. 

Worth visiting the original location as it provides a self-guided tour of the chocolate making process. Fun!

Hubby got delivered the wrong flavor of milkshake and got it replaced within about 10 minutes. Not bad.
author: Pachi C.

description:
This review is primarily aimed at the chocolate store - not the soda fountain/sundae serving section. The prices in here are awful, and you can get Ghirardelli chocolates virtually anywhere these days. Candy shops, Duane Reade's in NYC, Walgreens in SF... So if you want a small SF-focused memento (like a box of chocolates that looks like a cable car), that's fine. But don't buy the bars here.

On a side note, if you go in for a sundae with friends or as a couple, this place is awesome.
author: Aaron F.

description: I think I may have picked the wrong place to check in... but oh well, it's the same great ice cream and fudge they sell at the original shop (but just up the steps and the line is much shorter and they sell the same stuff) so ha!!... I think I actually went to the little coffee/ice cream shop that's a condensed quick stop version of the original but I digress... The point it, it was DELICIOUS!!  Have been waiting forever to have the precious Ghiradelli sundae with it's delicious fudge sauce since I had visited san fran before and I just stared like a sad fat kid into the window display with my mouth wide open staring at those inside licking their spoons and savoring every teeny tiny bit of their ice cream sundaes that looked like heaven! The fudge is definitely crack sauce, no joke!! and they gave free samples of their chocolates and you could still buy their merchandise just like the big store.  Order a sundae with chocolate fudge (melted from their chocolates), you won't be disappointed!!
author: Jeanne W.

description: Great seasonal chocolates. I always come here when at the wharf.  It's crazy not to stop by and least get a free sample
author: Roger H.

description:
OK, this is embarrassing... it was 11:30PM on Friday nite and I had just finished baby sitting for my co-worker in SOMA... when I had the most intense craving for mint chip ice cream! But not just any mint chip ice cream (I could easily have gone to Safeway) it had to be Ghirardelli with their larger than average size chocolate chip chunks.

See, I've been a devoted fan of mint chip since the 3rd grade, so the size of the chips REALLY does matter. :)

Anyway, it was 11:30PM on a balmy Friday nite... I had to have my fix but had zero clue if Ghirardelli was still open. Thank goodness for Verizon 411, cuz they connected me in no time pronto. AND as fortune would have it GHIRARDELLI IS OPEN TIL MIDNIGHT ON WEEKENDS!

I zipped over and arrived at 11:50PM and there was STILL a line, but I didn't care... not even when I freaked some tourists out cuz I was in my PJ's (what else do you wear when you're babysitting?) ... when I got my single scoop of mint chip ice cream in a plain cake cone, everything just made sense.
author: Nenette Y.

description: omg the sundaes...got chocolate wasted on a fine sunday afternoon
author: Harry T.

description:
Yes, it's touristy, but have you had one of their hot fudge sundaes lately?  Holy crap!  

Get one.  Extra fudge.  Two spoons.  Nuts.  Whipped cream.  Feel like a tourist again, in love with old-timey San Francisco.  Oh, bring your sweetheart...  tres romantique.  But if you don't have a sweetheart*, go alone.  Yes, you will eat the whole thing yourself.  Trust me on this. 

-----------------------
* Applications to be MY sweetheart can be submitted via Yelp Compliment or Private Message to Scott W.
author: Scott W.

description:
Ghirardelli square is one of those places you always hate to admit liking when you live in a specific area. It's full of tourists, cliche as anything, etc. Why would I like this place?

Even though it is touristy, where else can you go at 10pm on a Monday night for an ice cream sundae after a nice meal on the wharf? They are a bit overpriced ($8 or so for a regular hot fudge) but big enough to share and that satisfying way to satiate your sweet tooth. More than that, you have the view of the Golden Gate Bridge from the square, more chocolate than you could ever want, and a nice walk along Embarcadero in order to get back to bart (and it is a reasonably far walk)

However, the sundaes are practically drowning in fudge. They taste amazing for a bit until everything starts to get melty and the fudge begins to solidify. Yet you keep eating because it tastes good and you spent the money to begin with. Yes, a good sundae, but it would be a lot better if it were half the size and could be eaten in a timely manner.

I've had better ice cream sundaes elsewhere, but this is a place everyone should try at least once, whether you're a native or a tourist to SF.
author: Stephanie H.

description:
Mint Chip Ice Cream + Vanilla Ice Cream...drizzled with Dark Chocolate Hot Fudge = PERFECT concoction for a cool autumn night. 

Huge portion of quality ice cream and fudge that feeds 2 people well for about $8. 

In the cutest, perfect setting (Ghirardelli Square).

Oh my god I want more now.
author: Gail N.

description:
Came here to end an eventful day at the Pier and boy did it hit the spot. The mint bliss with dark chocolate fudge...never has being a fatty felt sooooo good. Mint chocolate ice cream + vanilla + dark chocolate fudge + ghiradelli dark chocolate square and whipped cream...man I can't wait to go back and try their other flavors. My arteries need a rest first tho.

The free ghiradelli square samples were also a nice touch as well. The presentation of the entire ice cream and chocolate store was just gorgeous in the most simplest of ways as well. If you are in the bay, you should at least come here to check it out at least once.
author: Will M.

description:
The hot fudge sundaes kick ass here. The fudge tastes really good. However, the lines were really long and it took a while to get my sundae. 

Honestly I don't know what else to say. It wasn't that memorable in terms of the food (although the folks I was with made it great) or anything else. Might be nicer when there aren't tons of people here.
author: Martin B.

description: Yes, the lines can be somewhat long, but the actual wait isn't usually too long (I've never seen more than 10-15min waits).  It's a little crowded, but the sundaes are amazing!  This is a "must do" every time I go to San Francisco!
author: Kirven S.

description: Some seriously decadent stuff going on here. I had a chocolate shake that was so rich i thought I was going to go into shock. Very efficient and quick service...you order at the counter, sit down at a table with your order #, and they bring you your stuff within minutes. Lots of great-sounding sundaes and shakes on the menu, plus they sell brownies and cookies also. It's connected to a shop that sells all their chocolate so you know we were going home with a few bags.
author: Rich J.

description:
MISSION: ICE CREAM

We went to the doors on ground level at 9pm Sunday night and they were locked! Someone motioned for us to go downstairs. We walked around the corner and saw a line outside and figured that's where we were supposed to be. The line was moving so fast we hardly had time to read the menu. A friend and I got the something haight something (I just remember it had berries) to share and the other two of us got a hot fudge banana split. It would have been SO MUCH BETTER if the ice cream wasn't melted when you got it. Wtf? You dip your spoon in and out oozes melted ice cream. It was the same with the sundae too. I'd go here again, but the ice cream really shouldn't be melted when you get it. $7-$8 for a Ghirardelli ice cream. Oh, and it came with a square of chocolate too, and we got really lucky because it was my favorite (milk chocolate with caramel inside)!
author: Chloe N.

description:
"We'll have a brownie sundae with vanilla and cookie dough ice cream, no nuts."
"Do you have an allergy?"
"*blushes* Yes."
"Hold on, I have to have a manager talk to you."

According to Alex, this has never happened to him before at any establishment in the past.  The manager comes over and explains how the stuff was produced on the same machinery.  But once Alex clarified that as long as they are no nuts in the food given to us, we'd be fine, the manager gave the ok and allowed us to be ringed up by the cashier.  That was very responsible of them.  And even the receipt said ALLERGIC in big bold letters right above the "no nuts".  So anyone with a nut allergy (where stuff being processed on the plant won't bother you), they have your ass covered!  

We went and sat upstairs, the greatly sized sundae comes in a short period of time, minus a cherry too.  Perhaps it was too much of a close contamination with the nuts.  But it was oh so divine!!!  The fudge is the best part, I was making sure to eat every bit, even more than the ice cream itself!  Alex was loving it as well.  It's nice that this place is open late and on a Sunday night too.

I have to give props to Sofia, she was so kind!  As we were sitting there chowing down on this sundae, she comes up to us saying that she prepared this Espresso Chip sundae to show another employee how, and if we wanted it.  I said "absolutely", and went to town on the free mini sundae in a plastic cup (the top part was covered with nuts so Alex couldn't partake).

It's definitely touristy but if you are bringing someone to town who isn't familiar, they will enjoy.  As long as they aren't lactose intolerant, in which case, my condolences.
author: Lori D.

description: If you like fudge, this is the place to be.   Its great late night spot to share a hot fudge sundae + a side of fudge, even on the coldest of days.  Yes, there still will be a line out the door.
author: S F.

description:
Best Banana Split I've ever had. The Hot fudge brownie and some other cookie sundae are really good too. 

Any sundae on the menu could literally just heal a broken heart...

It can get a little crowded but that's a part of the experience. It's a great place to bring anyone, especially out of town friends.
author: Angelina F.

description:
When my sister was a student at UCLA, she'd phone me and tell me how she went to Pasadena's Ghiradelli's (which I hear is now closed) with a friend and got a sundae.

Now that I'm a student at Berkeley, I'm glad to call my sister (who is in Nowheresville, Michigan) and tell her that I just enjoyed a scrumptious Cookie Bottom Sundae at Ghiradelli's in SF.

It's really hectic on the weekends. Tourists left and right, outside and inside. But what a cute idea. Very few nice places like this where you can sit down with someone you like and have a conversation over a scrumptious sundae.
author: Melody L.

description:
5 stars for the excellent hot chocolate here. Best I've ever had. The mug it's served in is as big as a soup bowl! Now that's generous!! I wasn't a fan of the mountain of whipped cream but it looked pretty enough for a picture...
http://images16.fotki.com/v303/photos/3/32745/657170/CIMG0142-vi.jpg
author: Michelle G.

description: Of course my wife and I had to stop here while visiting San Francisco. I was hoping for a tour but it's only a storefront/restaurant. We had some sundaes and it was good but it could have been any good ice cream shop and didn't really convey the Ghirardelli chocolate experience for us. So I would say go ahead and stop by for an ice cream if you're in the Fisherman's Wharf area but it's not worth making it a destination.
author: Steve M.

description: I love taking out of towners here. I had an icecream craving at 10PM last night so we went to Ghirardelli with two friends visiting from Seattle. They are open until 11PM which is awesome when my icecream stomach starts growling after dinner. The brownie sundae was gia-normous and is great to share with one or two others.
author: Debbie C.

description:
Nonpareils! Why do I have to go to the G-Square store to find them?
Give me a box of them and I'm happy. I once bought a box and put them on my hot fudge sundae!  I like the ice cream, I love the chocolate and I hate the lines. Oh well.

When I'm here, I am a tourist.

"Everything in this room is *eat*able. Even I'm *eat*able. But that is called cannibalism, my dear children, and is in fact frowned upon in most societies." ~W.W. (05)
author: JayChan H.

description:
I've lived in San Francisco for seven years. In this time I have never been to Alcatraz, Angel Island, the TransAmerica Building or Ghiradelli Chocolate. I've been to Ghiradelli Square (Buena Vista for Irish Coffee of course) so I'm not like a total complete anti-tourist trap freak. Just pretty much so. I talk to people I don't know for a living, so no need for me to be tourist friendly as well, that's how I see it. However, my aversion of all things tourist has apparently precluded me from Ghiradelli ice cream sundaes so now I'm a little pissed. I guess I could write a letter to someone in the mayor's office requesting a special "No Tourists Allowed Day" at Ghiradelli but since Gavin has recently forced his whole administration to resign I suppose that is a moot point.

I'm off subject, sorry. Brain Freeze.

Anyway, remember when you were a little kid and your mom did something totally off the wall like serving you waffles for dinner? And you thought "wow, this is just about as good as it gets." Well, on the dinner menu tonight at our house was hot fudge sundaes. This was the request. It wasn't even  my idea, but I thought it was a good one.

So, not wanting to actually "cook" the hot fudge sundaes, we thought long and hard as to where to go and ended up at Ghiradelli.

Great choice, super good and kind of a fun dinner date (assuming you aren't actually expecting diner). I had the Very Berry Sundae and the boy had the Hot Fudge Sundae. The store was actually almost empty - I guess the tourist only come on the weekends. Everyone that works there is really friendly and overly nice. There is a cool little tour that shows you how chocokate is made, also  Makes you appreciate why people come from all over the world to visit our fair city. And, apparently, to eat our chocolate. Yum!
author: Megan L.

description:
The first time I went here, I had a VERY bad date experience. 
Melted icecream, too much fudge, too sweet, not enough cookies..It was so sad that it affected my mood. I couldn't speak to my date like a normal person because my disappointment was so overwhelming. How could Ghirardelli lack such effort into making this supposedly "heavenly sundae" ? 

Second time I went here, which was today, I had the earthquake with a bunch of people. I tried to forget about the past tragedy even though it hurt me so much, but I gave Ghirardelli a second chance. Cookies n Cream, Rocky Road, Coffee...you were all so good. But only for so long would you make me happy... After 5 minutes, the rest melted into a state of apathy. Ghirardelli did this once, but how could it do this again to me?? 

It's hard to accept the fact that ice cream inevitably melts. I guess the saying is true: "Good things don't last forever."
author: Alexa M.

description: Chocolate + ice cream + chocolate + hot chocolate/ ice cream drinks + waffle cones + free Shiradelli square samples when you walk in = NUFF SAID!
author: Shawday B.

description:
I found out about this place recently and I love it, as I'm a huge choco-holic. 

I always get the brownie sundae when I go here which is big enough for two, I always split it with a friend. It is only $10 also, so a good light dinner topper or full on dinner haha. 

Also every time to you walk through the doors, either at the store front or the one that is upstairs, they give you a square of chocolate with caramel to sample. So of course, one walks through their doors twice. 

They also serve other desserts such as chocolate covered strawberries, drinks like hot chocolate and almost anything involved with chocolate. They also have a display of how their chocolate is made inside the store,
author: Tiara B.

description:
The original is still the best.

Sure, it's filled with tourists, but it's still a San Francisco institution. Come in for massive frozen desserts, wonderful gifts or just to get a free sample of chocolate. It's a fun place and the people who work here are always friendly.

For locals (with cars), check out the Ghirardelli factory in San Leandro for deals and access to super-fresh chocolate.
author: Keane L.

description:
It's winter... No more frapp's, slushies, snow bubbles, or jamba. That means I have to find a new high calorie drink to accompany me through this cold season. Luckily, I heard my co-worker talk about her trips to Ghirardelli Square for her hot chocolate fix and I knew I had found my new seasonal drink.

I love chocolate, yet I haven't had hot chocolate for years and I've never stepped foot inside GC. My bf and I agreed that it was time for a field trip. As we circled for parking, I noticed the tour buses unloading a buttload of tourists right in front of the square. By the time we parked and walked over the line snaked way out of the store. Waiting in the cold, my anticipation grew for something warm and delicious. After waiting to give our order, and then waiting for a table, then waiting for our drink... my expectations had gained steam...

... only to be shattered by the lukewarm watered down chocolate drink w/ whip (which I hadn't asked for). Leaving GC, I felt cheated and let down. The next day my bf made some delicious hot chocolate to make up for the sad sad experience here.

Tourists: you'll love this place.
Chocolate lovers: think twice... but take into account the free samples next door.
author: kat a.

description:
What would San Francisco be without the brightly-lit monumental Ghirardelli sign?

I'm not a major chocolate person, but they must obviously be good at what they do. I always need to share my sundae with someone because I cant finish it alone. And I personally find it too sweet and too rich, and I need to have several glasses of water nearby in order to enjoy my visit here. One time I had a sundae AND a hot chocolate, and I couldn't even make it to the bottom. My body almost went into shock from all that sugar. But I guess that means the chocolate quality is good right...

But it's clean, cozy, and monumental. I can just sit here enjoying my sundae with everyone else, and just soak up being in San Francisco, at Ghirardelli. And I like to walk my son around the "factory" side of the store that has the gigantic tubs of mixed chocolate. And then walk it off at the beach a few blocks down.
author: Joraine C.

description: The chocolate shakes were delicious and the device was nice, but the $18 price tag was a punch in the gut. The outdoor seating and general look of the square make it a nice place to visit and relax with a shake.
author: Curtis H.

description:
Quick seating and quick delivery of the desserts to the table.  Ordering is straight forward and the front entrance ordering counter provides free samples of individually packaged Ghiradelli brand chocolates; a definite PLUS!

Although my score is still a 3 star because of one instance where I was delivered a hot chocolate which included a black curly human hair in it...pubic?  I didn't want to find out; I put it aside and left it, feeling rather nauseous...
author: Terence K.

description:
I actually went to the smaller Ghiradelli Ice Cream Shop facing Beach Street. If you just wanna get ice cream and some of the chocolates, this one has a shorter line. The sign says Ice Cream To-Go. They serve the same sodas, sundaes, and shakes as the main fountain shop.

I decided to stray from the work masses and get a chocolate shake. Seriously, one of the best shakes I've ever had. Very thick and had bits of chocolate evenly distributed. It never lost its thickness and was sweet throughout. They server was friendly and was handing out samples like he was the pusher man!

At 5.25, a great alternative to a mocha drink at those other unnamed shops that just turns watery in about 5 minutes. As Russell Peters would say, it was mind-blasting, FUN-tastic!(Insert thick Indian accent)
author: Neil N.

description:
A little bit tourist-priced, but the ice cream was light and airy with delicious ghirardelli chocolate.  
Tip: look at the bottom of your receipt, if you are planning to go there again....
author: C D.

description:
Not the best place for ice cream sundaes, but it's still a good place to gather with some family and friends during the evening for some dessert. It does get overly crowded so you'll have to manuever your way through the groups of tourist.

There is almost always a line out the door so you'll want to look at their ice cream menu beforehand so that you're ready to order once you reach the counter. Once you've ordered, you pay, get a number to place on your table, and find a seat. Your order will be brought to you.

Here's the problem with this place. It's ice cream, so yeah it'll melt if left out too long. I would think most of us would like to eat our ice cream BEFORE it melts into some watery mess. So this place being crowded, the staff takes awhile before they can find you and by the time you get your ice cream everything has melted away. You wonder if you've ordered ice cream or a smoothie. I will give them credit for taking back our "sundae" and making us a new one that looks more presentable and taste much better. 

If you've never been here before, just come for the experience. As with any place in SF, parking is very difficult.
author: Veronica H.

description: I had to come visit the Ghirardelli Ice Cream & Chocolate Shop during my trip to SF. I expected this place to serve the best sundae but it turned out to be mediocre. Having visiting SF in mid-February, the weather was pretty cold and very windy. I didn't expect there to be long line waiting to order but surprisingly there was on the cold evening that I went. For someone with a big sweet tooth, this place is for you. Their menu is to die for. My husband and I ordered a chocolate brownie sundae. Seating is first come - first serve. Being in a party of 4 with a 6 month old, it was pretty hard. This place was crowded. Everyone was fighting for a seat. By the time we got our sundae, the ice cream was practically melted. The 2 scoops of ice cream was minimal. However, they gave a good serving of their chocolate syrup and brownie. I would give this review more stars if my ice cream wasn't already melted and if my serving of ice cream was bigger. Maybe it was just a really busy night and an off-day the day I went. I would go back and try them again. After all, their chocolates are really good. I was able to taste it in the brownie and sundae syrup.
author: Pugsly W.

description:
Good: Great chocolate and great presentations on the confections and ice cream sundaes. Quaint atmosphere (downstairs).
Bad: Long lines. Ice cream is okay. Waffle bowls are not good here. Go somewhere else, even Disneyland has better bowls (they are quite tasty!).
Final: Go for the one time experience then find a better tourist attraction.
author: Jonathan C.

description:
Being a fan of the Miami location, we had to check out the original.

A little different from Miami. You order at the front and you grab a sign with your number and try to find a table (which was pretty hard to find). The ice cream was actually not as chocolaty as Miami especially the brownie. I don't know why, but seriously it just wasn't. It still wasn't that bad. Still chocolaty that most places, so I couldn't complain.

It was cool that you can see chocolate being made in the back from some type of chocolate making machine. If I lived here I probably wouldn't bother. It is almost a tourist trap.
author: Len D.

description:
Not impressed - their chocolate is waxy and not really very good.

I only go here with out of town visitors. Its fun the first time but after that forget it. Of course all the sundaes are overpriced and the to-go sundae seemed especially small - maybe it was an illusion I dunno.
author: Chili B.

description: Ghirardelli is just an absolute San Francisco thing.  The square is super cute and tucked away enough that its not as in your face tourist trap as other parts of the city.  Their ice cream was very well flavored without being too sweet, as some Ghirardelli pieces tend to be.  My favorite was the milk peanut butter and the milk carmel.  Their dark chocolate was unimpressive, but not bad.
author: Andrea C.

description:
As much as I love this place, I uncovered major flaws tonight.

1) The glasses are really warm, so don't be surprised if by the time you get the ice cream half of it has already melted. I understand that the glasses are warm because they just came out of the dishwasher, but can't they get more glasses and put the warm ones in the fridge? I don't want to drink the ice cream.

2) After you order, you put the metal like hanger thing with your number on the table, and the busboys look for the number to bring you your order. Bad, bad idea! The place gets pretty crowded and the busboys have a difficult time finding the number in the ENTIRE Ghirardelli's. I am an observer, as any psychology student, and I saw the worried and troubled looks on some of the busboys faces when they just couldn't find the customers.

I remember seeing a busboy tell the guy behind the counter that he couldn't bring the ice cream to the person because it melted to a great extent (he couldn't find where the customers were sitting), but the guy who made the ice cream responded with something like "I already made it twice, I can't make it again, find them!"

Advice for the staff/manager: First, find out where the customers are sitting, and THEN make the ice cream (hopefully the people won't switch seats. haha). OR, seat customers yourself. You'll save yourself the trouble of walking around the whole place for 10 min or more while the vanilla-chocolate-caramel goodness melts away on your tray. In other words, this place might need waiter service.

3) Advice for the customer: After making an order (especially if you and your friends ordered together), make sure that all of the orders are on the receipt. Tonight, one of the cashiers forgot to enter my order. After we realized this and approached her, she didn't even apologize and just took the order as though she didn't do anything wrong. I'm not sure how this happened since she asked me twice how I wanted the ice cream. Bad service.
author: Narina A.

description:
If you're in SF ... you have to come here.  It's simply a staple that you cannot go home w/o.  Everything from coffee to ice cream sundae's ... and those oh so good samples you get in the beginning ... YUM!  

I highly rec'd you get the earthquake sundae and share it w/friends!  You can choose tons of ice cream flavors and the sundae will remind you of the good ole childhood days.  Man o man, I jones-ing for some right now ...
author: Roni R.

description: I'll admit it, this place is a tourist trap, but it's a trap this tourist enjoyed falling in to. We didn't bother buying chocolate because even on the east coast, you can get the chocolate in any CVS or convenience store that has chocolate. However, we did get the standard sundae (9.50$ I think), and it was DELICIOUS. We got it in the waffle cone bowl that is dipped in chocolate. This sundae was truly satisfying and was worth the wait. The line was HUGE, but it actually moved very quickly, and we got our ice cream very quick. This is a tourist trap that is definitely worth stopping at. It's a little pricey, but the sundae is freaking delicious.
author: Sam O.

description: Chocolate is always good, but this company is quite better than others. that's why the price is also up there. They always have what you want there for desserts. mmmmmmmmmmm
author: Darlene Q.

description:
Imagine a scene where within 10 feet of you are 38 screaming kids, 14 people wandering around looking for a table they will never find, (all the while carrying around a ridiculous looking metal stand with a number on it), 8 annoying tourists breathing down your neck and standing too close....and one too fuckin' cheerful for me nitwit handing out free squares of insipid chocolate.
There you have it - my Ghiradelli Choco experience in a nutshell.....

Also, $7.50 for a bowl full of whipped cream and nuts is a doozy.....if you call that a hot fudge sundae.....
author: Vik S.

description: More a tourist spot than a good dessert spot. Due to its location, the place is extremely busy and you will have to make do with tables that are not clean. The sundaes are good although overpriced.
author: Bala L.

description:
I've come here several times with people as a tourist. Now that Ghirardelli chocolates can be found everywhere, the candy store and ice cream shop is less appealing. The place is packed with tourists and the quality of the ice cream sundaes has suffered. Although they are still rich and loaded with fudge, they are no longer carefully made. The butterscotch or fudge always finds its way to the bottom, threatening to hurt one's teeth. The sundaes can no longer compare to the ones I've had in the past. 

Do yourself a favor and go to a less touristy location.
author: Amy B.

description: This place is actually a very cool place to head to in the city, if it's some sweet stuff with friends that you want. Of course, the place is always packed (thanks to all the tourists), so service is on the slow side. But once that stuff hits your table, get ready for cold sweets that are hard to beat. Hey, that rhymed! Anyhoo, yeah, it is a bit on the expensive side... but if you want a treat with all of your friends (and save some dough in the process), order the Earthquake. Basically, it's a gigantic sundae made to accomadate several people. Good stuff. Just wish it wasn't so slow. C'est la vie.
author: Eric A.

description:
awesome sundaes, shady management.

high turnover, they lay off solid long term employees and hire immature teens
author: Samantha W.

description: It's the world famous Ghirardelli house of chocolate... 'nuff said.
author: Zinat M.

description: The Ocean Beach sundae is to die for. The ice cream is delicious, but during peak hours they've been known to mess up your order, which is understandable. Just be patient with them.
author: Janet R.

description: Last stop before going to the airport and home. Had to have a hot fudge sundae here. At first I hesitated because it was $8.50 but what the heck I was on vacation. It was very crowded but the line moved along. The cashier took our order and offered us a free piece of their new chocolate flavor. When the sundae arrived it was just in a plastic cup with their name on it of course. I got the dark chocolate fudge and there was plenty of it on the vanilla ice cream scoops. It was good and I ate the whole thing. I probably would not do it again if I was in SF as I think it is a one time touristy thing you have to do.
author: Lynn K.

description:
Didn't have to patience to deal with the cockamamie way they have placing orders and seating, so we left the joint when the kid out the counter decided to turn his back on us when he realized we weren't with the other party at the counter...after he had already asked me what I wanted.

But I'm not that huffy.  I will still continue to brew my Ghiradelli's chocolate coffee in the morning (that is, in a blend of 4 parts Peets coffee and 3 parts Ghiradelli's).
author: Jens J.

description:
This is a great place to take your Aunt Dorothy from Iowa and your Uncle Elmer from Wisconsin.  It's also a pretty darn good ice cream shop.

If you don't mind waiting in line for a couple of minutes (15 minutes on busy nights) and you don't mind elbowing a few tourists to grab one of the few available tables, you're in for a treat.  In fact, it's a dinner AND a show for a low, low price of about $8.  

First of all, it's people watching of a whole different kind.  Observing tourists in their (un)natural habitat is both fun and entertaining.  You can watch them struggle with their maps, shivering on a cold San Francisco night.  You can watch them try to juggle their cameras, their kids and their boxes of Ghirardelli chocolate.  Finally, you can watch them try to pretend their lime green "Alcatraz" shirt goes with their bright pink "I love SF" baseball cap.  Priceless.

The ice cream here is really good, although the fat content in their desserts is probably high enough to kill you.  I prefer the Very Berry Sundae, which is vanilla ice cream with blueberry jam, whipped cream and chocolate covered blueberries.  It's really, really good.  The banana split, also highly recommended, is 10,000 calories of fatty goodness.  The ice cream itself is sweet, creamy and delicious.

Bottom line is, the ice cream is not as good as Mitchell's, but better than most other places.  The price is right, and the surroundings are much nicer.  Go!  Your Aunt Dorothy and Uncle Elmer will thank you.
author: Yan G.

description:
Holy candy store and ice cream stand, Batman!

The line of tourists is long but it moves fairly quickly. If you like water with your ice cream, don't buy it there's free water to be had beyond the register. If you don't like lines or people there's another Ghirardelli  ice cream stand nearby. Explore the square for a few minutes and you'll find it.
author: Andrew B.

description: Went here after fisherman's wharf for some ice cream. They gave out a free sample of chocolate at the door. You go downstairs to where the magic happens. It wasn't that exciting. My friend and I shared a hot fudge sundae. It had too much hot fudge, way to chocolatey for our taste. The vanilla ice cream wasn't anything great. It was overpriced and not worth it. The wait wasn't bad because it's not that hard to make but eh, I was over it after I got the free sample of peppermint chocolate.
author: Lyly T.

description:
The ice cream sundaes here are delicious, an awesome place to get totally fat. The amount of ice cream that comes with your sundae is outrageous! and it's so cute cause it's all topped with a teeny tiny red cherry.

Their hot cocoa on a cold ass day is good too.

Friendly FYI: If you can, park at the bottom of the hill so that all the hard work of climbing the damn thing to get to the shoppe is taken care of before you eat. You don't want stomach cramps from climbing a hill right after you stuff yourself do you?
author: Richard T.

description:
You have to try this place at least once even if you're not a fan of sweets like me. It's on a top of a hill with the big Ghirardelli sign. It's definitely a landmark. They have a nice sit down restaurant in the square but San Franciscans tend to avoid that unless they want to sit down really bad. It's mainly tourists who get suckered into that. 

You want to go up the street into the corner shop where they do pick up orders. They are quite fast except on weekends where there are events.

I had the Very Berry sundae. Very good. It's strawberry swirl ice cream with whip cream, nuts, a chocolate cigar wafer thingy, and blueberries that have chocolate inside. Oh, and of course, hot chocolate Ghiradelli fudge.
author: James L.

description:
The aroma as soon as you walk into the factory/store is amazing!!Literally makes you drool.

Chocolate, chocolate, chocolate everywhere! I'm not much of a chocolate person but I am a major fan of Ghirardelli Squares. 

Milk chocolates seriously just melts in your mouth. Yum....

Gift shop is nice. Good gifts for chocolate lovers.
author: Betty D.

description: So delicious!  I loved the traditional sundae.  You can watch the chocolate being made and then eat your sundae in it's aromatic glory.  If you're down by Fisherman's Wharf, you must try this!
author: Rick R.

description:
Mileu:
any ice cream parlor, but packed with people and tourists.  Hell no will i ever go back there unless my friends are visiting.

Service:
like any tourist restaurant

Food:
For some reason, I thought it tasted much better.  Brownie was NOT good.  So dense, I think they forgot to cook it or at least warm it up.   Second, they over power you with so much whip cream, you hardly get any ice cream. Down with Ghiradelli's corporate trying to save money on food when they are making millions of dollars per year.  Share your wealth dammit....HAHAHHA
author: M L.

description: Oh my goodness! I love this place! The desserts and service are amazing here! I got my Very Berry Sundae within 5 minutes. I love how there's a store in the same building so you can buy chocolate too. And also they had the whole process of how they make the chocolate in the shop. Pretty cool! Since it is Ghirardelli make sure you have at least $10 since everything is around $6-10 except for The Earthquake which is around $30. It tastes great and the place is just awesome. You should go when you're around Fisherman's Wharf!
author: Fanny Y.

description: Really awesome place to go to when you are showing someone around in SF.. The domingo is probably the best thing to order if its your first time.. really awesome sundae with lots of bananas, gooey fudge and cream.. yummy!!
author: Aditya M.

description:
The chocolate is very uninteresting but some variety has been proven to improve the health of those eating it in bed with a glass of grapefruit juice.

Forgetting to brush your teeth afterward has a synergistic effect on the chocolate/grapefruit combo and is highly recommended.
author: Bobby T.

description: Yummmm! It was late at night and they still had a line! Who could say no to dessert, especially chocolate! The hot chocolate is amazing, perfect for San Francisco's chilly weather. It was rich and chocolaty. I had their peanut butter sundae in a chocolate dipped waffle cone. The vanilla ice cream topped with hot fudge was perfect! The peanut butter however, was a bit overpowering. I'd love to come back and try the rest of the sundaes!
author: Karen L.

description: Not a fan.  Same as the one in Chicago, namely, overpriced and over-sweet.  Quality of the chocolate doesn't hold a candle to La Maison du Chocolat or Teuscher.  I would say even Godiva beats this hands down.  A tourist trap for sure, and I would seriously recommend avoiding this shop unless it is on your tick-box of things to do in SF or Chicago.
author: Peter S.

description:
I've been coming here since middle school, and of all the ice cream combos I like, I prefer the earthquake and any of the caramel or hot fudge sundaes.  I don't know if they even have the earthquake anymore since I didn't see it on the menu last night.  But if you're lactose intolerant, you'll probably crap your pants by just inhaling the smell.

It's also a great place during the cold rain too!  They have creamy hot cocoa choices to fill the empty void that the frigid temps give you.

Great date place, and some advice, do NOT stick your finger to taste the 'chocolate' in the mill.  The sneeze barriers are there for a reason.  It's not for you to taste.  Silly tourists.
author: Alfred Y.

description: Look no further, they have an amazing selection of sweets and sugary food here(though its hello obesity!) Once you go in here, the place is small but it feels like you are in a chocolate factory. They have like a machinery of what it looks like a chocolate making machine. Pretty cool i must say. Their sundae is hella sweet for all of us sweet lovers here and i really fancy their hot chocolate. Hmmmm how do I describe it...i can taste little bits of heaven! Its not just sweet but you can really taste the cocoa! Not disappointed in this place and def would go here again!
author: Cavin T.

description: The Sundays are excellent but expensive, 9+ tax for a not that big Sunday.... Id go to Ben and Jerry's nearby
author: Mark B.

description: This was fun. I liked it here, nice and peaceful. I love chocolate!
author: Jimmy K.

description:
Ghiradelli: the best chocolate from San Francisco! 

This is my hometown favorite, with a delightful assortment of chocolate flavored-anythings. If you have a chocolate craving, Ghiradelli is the place. 

Located near Aquatic Park/The Cannery in the city, this place offers a delicious selection of soda fountain drinks and desserts. If you want a banana split or a triple fudge sundae, you will have it covered with sweet treats and of course, the Ghiradelli chocolate. 

Some desserts come with a chocolate square, giving their sundaes/desserts their trademark touch. The small shop is usually VERY crowded because it's located in a touristy place by the pier/Fisherman's Wharf. So do prepare to wait in line and for your dessert to arrive at your table once you've placed your order. 

There's also a small store next to the fountain shop, so you can pick up your favorite chocolates as gifts to take home with you!
author: Melinda L.

description:
Mmmmmm, this place is very tasty.  Ghirardelli Square is a must-visit anytime you're showing friends or relatives from out of town the SF touristy sites.  And if you're in Ghirardelli Square, you have no excuse - you have to visit the chocolate shop.

Besides being able to watch them make chocolate-dipped strawberries, you can order some of the most delicious ice cream concoctions on the northern side of SF.  (I really like the brownie sundae).  These sundaes are pretty big, though, so I recommend splitting one between two people.

There are going to be big lines and its a little pricey, but if you're in the area and like ice cream and chocolate, you have to check it out.
author: Chad H.

description: Great ice cream flavors w Espresso Chip and Coffee flavors really hit the spot.
author: David M.

description: I admit I'm addicted to Chocolate and have to relate to others this is the best place to get your chocolate fix for the day!  Right at the door your offered free samples that just get your mind and taste sensors primed for what awaits.  The aroma that emits from here is heavenly.  Any time we're in the city and have a desire for ice-cream we go no where else but  here to Ghirardelli Square and enjoy being submerged in chocolate bliss.  Even now writing this review is driving my taste buds to long for that smooth, rich, chocolate to pass over them...may have to make an emergency trip back today to enjoy again.  Miss you already Ghirardelli and see you again very soon!
author: John F.

description:
For some reason every time I have ever visited Ghirardelli Square it has always been freezing outside and/or raining! But it won't stop me from visiting their cafe for old fashioned ice cream sundaes and floats.  
Their coke floats with chocolate ice cream win me over every time. Who knew chocolate and coke would marry together so well?! I love watching their chocolate making process; everyone does it differently. Its a great place to get something sweet while visiting Fisherman's Wharf for the day. One of my favorites!
author: Christine L.

description: A must for tourists, city dwellers, and South Bay dwellers alike. There's something fun about going here at all hours, whether during the day during a tourist like jaunt through Fisherman's Wharf, or late at night on a romantic date. The ice cream and chocolates here are always consistently good. My favorites are the banana split, the berry sundae, and a chocolate waffle cone with mint chocolate chip ice cream. I also love the samples they give out! Mm!
author: Katherine P.

description:
Locals turn up our noses at tourist traps, but like a moth to a flame burned by the fire (i had to, sorry) I will go to Ghiradelli in a heartbeat if someone else is driving. Just kidding. 

Yes, it's packed with tourists, but where else can you really feel lucky to have this in your backyard? Everyone wants you to bring them some ghiradelli straight from the kitchen whenever you travel because I ain't carrying boudin's on a plane. I'll probably eat it waiting on the tarmac to taxi. I'm weak like that.

I was recently there and pleased to find the upstairs was pretty empty and the scoopers/lackeys were hanging about. Downstairs was where the thundering herd was chillin', so skip that if you can. Squares are to die for, so  make sure you get one, two for auntie, and three, four and five for you.

Warm days will bring the crowds. Cooler ones will bring the hardcore, but there will always be a crowd. Prepare to be satiated.
author: Charlene L.

description:
Pretty much the stores are only in California, Florida, Vegas, Chicago, so of course, there's gonna be lots of tourists.  Walk in for a free sample at any location (usually chocolate caramel).  Circle around to get another.
Hot chocolate is nice, especially in the evening when it's a bit colder.  Plus it's nicer to go late night when all the tourists are gone.  This location has the little area in the back showing you how it's made.
author: Rob C.

description:
Lose a star for price. Lose 3 stars as they lost our 3 orders. Once we figured they lost our order and we had to tell them what we ordered they did serve us. No sorry we lost it, just gave us our food.

Average ice cream. Expensive. Bad service. At least on this one trip.
author: D E.

description:
Other than Mitchell's ice cream, this is the next best thing.

As always, I love the ambience, especially at night.  There's a variety of flavors to choose from, but I always go with the Earthquake special which, ironically, costs $19.06.  The chocolate here is also the very best I've tried.  Good atmosphere, great place to get it on with ice cream, and great location make this one hell of a place.
author: Joe V.

description:
After gorging ourselves on Argentinian grilled meats, our party of six headed up to Ghirardelli Square to tackle on an Earthquake. The place was packed on a Sunday evening, circa 830p, after much finagling and scouting, we secured a table.

The Earthquake arrived and it was mighty. We dug in, rotating the platter every few bites so that we could all share in the variety of flavors. And saliva. Thankfully, we're all friends. And so we ateth and please were our stomachs. The only complaint of the evening was that there a complete and utter lack of hot fudge in our Earthquake. Sad. Boo.

3.5 stars for now, though things may change with future visits - of which there will be, since the girlfriend is inordinately fond of the place.
author: Albert C.

description:
OMG! its super rich and oozing milk chocolate melt thickly spread on the sides with lots (that's LOtS) of sprinkled pecans all over!!!
it was sooooooo good i felt like a kid walking and nibbling and licking my lip like theres no more for tomorrow!!! me and the touring gang really enjoyed this one (to compensate for the long walks dear). 
one of the best frozen creams ive ever tasted, unlike others which make you feel like finishing up a cup of ice cream like a chore.

!!! count my exclamation points to taste how good my fudge was. c"')
author: Athens r.

description: Great familiar taste and reliable menu choices. Friendly faces and attentive staff. Limited accommodation for overflowing guess at times.
author: Aung W.

description: Fun tourist spot if you can stand the insane crowd but for sure--the menu is worth it. We underestimated ourselves and got the brownie sundae, an espresso sundae (I can't recall the exact name) and drinkable chocolate with a biscotti. Honestly, the drinking chocolate would have been JUST fine. The latter was the most memorable for me -- bitter, dense in flavor and warm for a SF day. :) The biscotti had a perfect softness, too. I loved, loved, loved it. :) Prepare to fight for a table and don't forget to talk a walk around the counter to see how their chocolate process works.
author: Cinna M.

description: I love Ghirardelli Chocolate Ice Cream Shops and I really wish there was a location in Manhattan. How could I pass a Ghirardelli Chocolate Ice Cream Shop without stopping in for a sundae, especially in San Francisco?! (I actually went in twice during my 4-day visit. Their hot chocolate is perfection.) This is, by far, the largest Ghirardelli Chocolate store and ice cream shop I've stepped foot in as it takes up a whole city block.
author: Amy C.

description: So much overhype about the sundae here. Waiters and cashiers apparently don't know what manners are and have no idea what a smile is. Just tour the square and do not enter the shop.
author: Umut G.

description:
This place is like one of the well known landmarks in SF. It just attracts the crowd. People would not care if their kids got lost amidst the long wait lines, because all they want is to taste their chocolate desserts here! Is that why so many kids cry in front of this place?? 

Parking can be hectic, I tell ya. Make a wrong turn and you go bye bye for a while until you find the way back. I've seen 2 minor accidents here already. Can you local SF people respect that there are scary grannies and grandpas who are not used to driving on roller coaster type of streets and stop honking?! 

Everyone comes out of this place with a smile too. Last time just before entering, my gf and I had some stupid little argument. Sure enough, the chocolate sundae silenced her, ha. Girls just love sweet stuff. 

It is a crime to travel to SF with a girl without taking her to Ghirardelli!
author: Takechiyo L.

description: Heard of candy-land? Now enter chocolate-land.  A MUST visit if you have a sweet tooth and love chocolate.  I always leave with a smile and a very happy tummy.
author: Cindy T.

description: The classic hot cocoa was a nice touch after coming from Off the Grid in the freezing cold since it is close to the water.  It was smooth and not too thick, complemented with the whipped cream on top, making it a perfect after dinner specialty.  This really warms you up from the cold weather.  I would come back to try some of the other desserts next time, but overall, it was good.  The service was extremely fast and the place is extremely packed and noisy, so finding a place to sit may be a bit of a task.
author: Lawrence E.

description:
With 363 preexisting reviews, I'm sure you don't need another!  Thus, I'll keep it brief.  It's Ghirardelli, so you'd be damned if you haven't already heard of what they make, and they're damn good at it.

The one reason this isn't a 5-star rating is because it's so frickin' busy!  That's both good and bad for them, but I say it's just bad.  You can't serve more customers than you can seat!
author: Garett T.

description: Talk about being a kid in a candy store, literally. Who can pass up a free sample of delicious chocolate? The selections of chocolates here are plentiful. I couldn't make up my mind as to what I wanted to purchase, eventually settling on a 50 count assorted bag of goodies. Prices are reasonable, but really can one spend too much for chocolate? Next time I'll try the ice cream.
author: Joseph C.

description: I know I am crazy, but I am not a big sweets fan. Although, I made an exception with this place. I had a great coffee mocha with a brownie. Yes it was amazing, but I recommend getting some water also. Consider yourself warned, Your eyes will be  larger than your stomach! If your female friend is celebrating that "special" time of month, she is going to love you for taking her to this place!
author: Steve W.

description:
It's been a bit since I've been to Ghirardelli. Part of the reason is because I like to avoid the touristy places and this place does get packed with camera ready visitors. Watch out for the bush guy if you're visiting.

Every time I've ever been here, the line is insane to buy chocolate. The chocolate is pretty good, but you can go to any grocery store and buy the same stuff. But if you're looking for the SF experience, then the line won't be so bad for you. The thing that you can't get at the store is their ice cream sundaes. I get something with "Gold" in the title and it was the best. I later had to go get my arteries unclogged, but it was well worth it. 

Recommend ice cream, but buy the chocolate at any store around the Bay Area to save time and money.
author: CLINTON W.

description:
My boyfriend and I visit the smaller cafe all the way in the back of the inner plaza but I guess all three cafes (including the smaller one on the corner of beach and larkin) are all the same...

I usually go here because he loves the sundaes. I don't know where else that has hot dark chocolate fudge. Nevertheless, I wish they did give more ice cream. But last night's visit was noteworthy:
